Gabel, Arthur
Born: Aug 14, 1907, died: Apr 1986, residence: Beallsville
 
Gainer, Howard L.
Source-News Register Wheeling, West Virginia
Published--June 15, 2003
Howard L. Gainer, 73, of Pine Grove, West Virginia., died Friday, June 13, 2003 in Marietta Memorial Hospital, Marietta, Ohio.
He was born July 15, 1929 in Reader, West Virginia,, the son of the late Glenn and Panseye Gainer.
He was retired from Ormet Corportation, Hannibal, Ohio.
He was preceded in death by his wife, Mary Jo Bates Gainer on July 2, 1997; a grandson, Justin Reed Gainer; and a sister, Freda Sapp.
Surviving are two sons, Phillip Gainer of Fairmont, West Virginia and Ralph Gainer of Pine Grove, West Virginia; two daughters, Gloria Fluharty of Piney and Glenda Gainer of Pine Grove; and four grandchildren, Kellena Fluharty Miracle of North Carolina., Bobby Fluharty of Piney and Ralphie and William Gainer, both of Pine Grove.
There will be no visitation. Graveside services will be held at 3 p.m. Sunday at the Knights of Pythias Cemetery, Pine Grove, West Virginia.
Arrangements by the Palmer Funeral Home, Incorporated, Pine Grove.
Sunday News-Register - Wheeling, West Virginia - Sunday, June 15, 2003

Gallagher, Mary Starr

Mary Starr, nee Gallagher

Mary E. Starr, 64, a resident of Route 3, Woodsfield, died June 11, in Mt. Carmel East Hospital, Columbus. She was born Nov. 12, 1918 at Eldon, OH, a daughter of the late George and Sallie Goodhart Gallagher.

She was a member of St. Mary s Catholic Church, Temperanceville and the Catholic Women s Club.

She was preceded in death by a brother and her step-mother.

Surviving are her husband, Everett Starr; three daughters, Mrs. Virgil (Alice) Rush of route 1, Quaker City, Mrs. Robert (Sallie) O Dell and Mrs. Tom (Connie) Kessler, both of Reynoldsburg; a son, Charles of Reynoldsburg; three sisters, Mrs. Walter (Pearl) Reischman of Barnesville, Mrs. Paul (Leola) Brown of Newark, and Mrs. Thomas (Martha) Terry Jr. of Reynoldsburg; two brothers, Joseph Gallagher of Malaga and Gerard Gallagher of Lore City; 10 grandchildren.

Friends were received at the Campbell-Plumly Funeral Home, Barnesville. Mass of Christian Burial was Monday in St. Mary s Catholic Church, with the Rev. Joseph Massucci the celebrant. Burial in St. Mary s Cemetery, Temperanceville.

 
Gallagher, stella
Stella Gallagher
 
Stella Gallagher, 94, of Woodsfield, formerly of Marietta Street, Sardis, died Saturday, March 19, 2005, at the Woodsfield Nursing Home.
She was born Oct. 25, 1910, in Sardis, the daughter of the late Clem and Cora Bennett Stewart.
 
She was a member of Mt. Olive United Methodist Church.
 
In addition to her parents, she was preceded in death by her husband, Charles Gallagher, and one sister, Blanche Hubbard.
 
Surviving are a son, Richard (Jeanine) Gallagher of Dearbourne Heights, Mich.; three grandsons, Donald Gallagher of Ogden, Utah, Daniel Gallagher of New Hartford, N.Y., and Dennis Gallagher of Taylor, Mich.; and six great-grandchildren.
 
The family will receive friends on Monday from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. at the Grisell Funeral Home, 37234 Mound St., Sardis, where funeral services will be held on Tuesday at 3 p.m. with Rev. Frank Conley officiating. Interment will take place in Mt. Olive Cemetery.
 
Sympathy expressions at www.grisellfuneralhomes.com.
Source: The Times Leader, Saturday, March 19, 2005

Mrs. Charlotte GAMBS
Source:The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., April 27, 1916
Collection of Gertrude Christman Kahrig
Mrs. Charlotte GAMBS, nee YOCKEY, widow of John GAMBS, died near Smithland, Iowa, last week. She leaves four children, three brothers, Louis, John and Edward YOCKEY of Smithland, Iowa. Her remains were interred in the Smithland cemetery, services being conducted by the pastor of the Evangelical Church of which she was a life Long member.
 
Gandy, Kelly Lee, nee Stottlemire
Source--Marietta Times Marietta, Ohio
Published--October 15, 2004
Kelly Lee Gandy, 44, of 218 Broughton Avenue, Marietta, died at 7:55 p.m. Wednesday ,October 13, 2004 at Marietta Memorial Hospital. She was born September 12, 1960, in Sistersville, West Virginia., to Robert R. and Carolyn Flanagan Stottlemire. She was a member of the Nazarene Church and was employed in home nursing. She graduated from Frontier High School in 1978. She is survived by one daughter, Tyra Gandy of Waterford; one son, Robert Gene Gandy of Marietta; two grandchildren, Devin and Shane; her parents, Robert and Carolyn Stottlemire of New Matamoras; two brothers, Timothy Ray Stottlemire of New Matamoras, and Robert Stottlemire Jr. and his wife, Kelly, of New Matamoras; her fiance, Larry Loy of Marietta; and her paternal grandmother, Lucy Stottlemire of Sistersville, West Virginia. She was preceded in death by her grandfather, Walter Stottlemire; and her maternal grandmother, Dolly Elizabeth Kemp. Services will be at 1 p.m. Saturday at Hadley Funeral Homes, New Matamoras Chapel, with the Reverend Frank Conley officiating. Burial will be in Matamoras Cemetery. The family will receive friends from 2 to 4 and 6 to 8 p.m. today at the funeral home.

Gardner, Lori Ann and Thomas Allen Logston
This day I will marry my friend, the one I laugh with, live for, dream with, and love. This is the day we will vow our love before our family, frineds and God above. In years to come as we recall, again we'll thank you, one and all. All who came from far and near, we're grateful for your presence here, and may God bless you, this we pray as He has us this wedding day. Lori and Thomas
Mr.and Mrs. Larry Gardner and Mr. and Mrs. Richard Logston invite you to share in the joy of the marriage uniting their children Lori Ann Gardner and Thomas Allen Logston. This celebration of love will be Saturday, the twenty-second of October nineteen hundred and ninety-four at three-thirty in the afternoon at the Trinity United Church of Christ, Lewisville, Ohio. Source: Wedding invitation.

Gardner, W. Preston

Woodsfield-Services for W. Preston Gardner, 80, of 130 N. Main St., Woodsfield, owner and operator of Gardner Funeral Home for 57 years, will be at 2 p.m. Sunday at Woodsfield Church of Christ. The Rev. Harry Summers will officiate. Burial will be in Oaklawn Cemetery.

Friends may call from 7 to 9 p.m. Saturday at Gardner Funeral Home. The body will be taken to the church one hour prior to the services.

Mr. Gardner died at 10:08 p.m. Thursday (Dec. 25, 1980) at Barnesville Hospital following a long illness.

He was born May 31, 1900, in Monroe County, son of the late James Madison and Nevada Moberly Gardner. He was a 1931 graduate of Columbus School of Embalming. Mr. Gardner was a member of Woodsfield Church of Christ, Stafford Masonic Lodge 300, Gideon s International Organization and the Full Gospel Fellowship. He was a past member f the Woodsfield school board.

Mr. Gardner married the former Madge Robinson, who survives, on Jan 6, 1923. He also leaves two sons, the Rev. James Gardner of North Lawrence and Robert Gardner of Stafford; four grandchildren; one great-grandchild; one brother, Madison Gardner Jr. of Rinard Mills; and two sisters Mrs. Raymond (Grethel) Winland of Bremen and Mrs. Woodrow (Gladys) Crum of Graysville.

 

 
Gardner, Mr. and Mrs. Wick
Source--Monroe County Beacon Woodsfield, Ohio
Published--December 24, 1987
GRAYSVILLE--Mr. and Mrs. Wick Gardner of Route 1, Graysville will observe their 50th wedding anniversary, December 24.
Mrs. Gardner is the former Hattie Griffin, daughter of the late Russell and Ada Griffin of Graysville. Mr. Gardner is the son of the late Mervin and Hattie Gardner of Rinard Mills.
They were married in Woodsfield by Justice of the Peace, Earl Ward, on December 24, 1937.
Mr. Gardner is a retired mechanic from Switzerland of Ohio School District.
They are the parents of nine children: Mrs. Johnny (Ruth) Weckbacher of Lower Salem, Mrs. Kenneth (Betty) Eddy of Barnesville, Mrs. Duane (Juanita) Householder of Minerva, Mrs. Larie (Nancy) Conner of Graysville, Larry Edward Gardner of Graysville, Mrs. Larry (Ramona) Weckbacher of Lewisville, Mrs. Carolyn Carter of Winter Haven, Florida, Mrs. Randy (Debbie) Buckey of Sharon and Blaine Gardner of Oceanside, California.
Twenty-five grandchildren and two great-grandchildren complete the family circle.
 

 

 
Gardner, Wilbert

Gardner, Willard E.
Born:July 1, 1918
Apr 21, 1989
Woodsfield

1989

ANNIVERSARY

Gardner, Wilma Elizabeth and Samuel P. Reinke

The Reverend and Mrs. Samuel P. Reinke of Tulip Lane, Sarahsville, will celebrate their golden wedding anniversary on June 24.

They will be honored at a reception in the Congregational Church of Blooming Grove, N.Y, hosted by their sons, John M. Reinke of Seattle, Washington, Dr. David H. Reinke of Assonet, Mass.

The Reverend Mr. Reinke was pastor of the Blooming Grove Church for nine years, where he and Mrs. Reinke lived for 18 years before moving to Ohio.

On June 24, 1939, Wilma Elizabeth Gardner and Samuel P. Reinke were united in marriage in the Trinity Methodist Church, Cleveland. The father of the bridegroom, the late Reverend Theodore Reinke, officiated assisted by the late Reverend Charles Clark.

The Reinkes have served parishes of the Congregational Christian Churches, the United Church of Christ and the Moravian Church in Minnesota, Florida, Ohio and New York as well as 15 years with the Universal Listening Post, a religious and educational fellowship. Since living in Sarahsville, the Reverend Mr. Reinke has served parishes as interim minister in Monroe County and Marietta.

Mrs. Reinke, a graduate of Case Western Reserve, taught school in Cleveland, Key West, FL. and New York, and has been substitute teacher in the Noble Local School District.

The Reverend Mr. Reinke is a graduate of Moravian College and Theological Seminary in Bethlehem, PA, has earned a master of sacred theology from Andover Newton Theological School, and has pursued other graduate work at Union Theological Seminary and Oberlin Graduate School of Theology.

In addition to their three sons, the family includes two daughters in law, Mrs. David (Jackie) Reinke and Mrs. Donald (Bonnie) Reinke and nine grandchildren.

The Reverend and Mrs. Reinke expect soon to be moving to Massachusetts.

 

Garrett, Charles
Born: May 2, 1891, died: July 1974, residence: Woodsfield
Source: Monroe County death records
 
Garrett, Esther M. (nee Bintz)
Galion, Ohio-Esther M. Garrett, 79, of 7714 Middletown Road died Sunday,
September 7, 1997, at her home after a Long illness.
Born February 5, 1918, in Monroe County, Ohio, to Elmer and Anna Pfalzgraf
Bintz, she moved to Galion in 1945 from Canton. She was a Cook for
Crestline High School for 15 years and served on the council at Calvary
United Church of Christ, Crestline, where she was a member.
Surviving are her husband, Tom Garrett, whom she married September 28,
1940; two sons and a daughter-in-law, Gill and Linda Garrett of Columbus and
Bob Garrett of Crestline; a daughter and son-in-law, Barb and Jack Stover of
Archbold, Ohio; seven grandchildren; and three sisters, Freda Wichterman of
Crestline, Rose Studer of Mansfield, and Leona Betz (Betts) of Copley, Ohio.
She was preceded in death by a sister, Sophia Bintz.
Calling hours are today from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. at the Mark A.
Schneider Funeral Home, Crestline. Funeral services will be held Wednesday
at 11 a.m. at Calvary United Church of Christ in Crestline by the Rev.
Martin Stiffler. Burial will be in Mansfield Memorial Park.
Memorial contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society or
Calvary United Church of Christ in care of the funeral home.
[Source:Mansfield News Journal, Mansfield, Ohio September 9, 1997, p. 8A]
 
 
Garrett, Jessie
Born: June 29, 1894, died: November 1977, residence: Woodsfield
 
Garrett, John E.
Published---1968
John Edward Garrett, 44, of Route 1, Sardis, Ohio, died Tuesday morning, March 12, 1968, at 9:30 o'clock in Barnesville General Hospital.
He was born September 26, 1921, at Alton, Illinois.
Mr. Garrett was an engineer at Ormet Corporation, Hannibal.
Surviving are his wife, Rose Ann Ellis Garrett; four step-children, Regina, Elizabeth, Tammy and Franklin Ellis, all of the home, and his mother, Mrs. Hazel Garrett, of Cheshire, Connecticut.
Funeral services were held Saturday afternoon at two o'clock in the Ratcliff - Wharton -Ellis Funeral Home, at New Martinsville, West Virginia, with the Reverend Ralph Young, of The First Baptist Church of New Martinsville, officiating. Burial was in Greenlawn Memorial Park, New Martinsville.
 
Garrett, Mildred A. Winland, nee Garrett
SOURCE: Daily Jeffersonian . . Cambridge, OH . . . July 2001
BARNESVILLE Mildred A. Winland, 79, of Malaga, died Tuesday (July 10, 2001) at Woodsfield Nursing and Rehabilitation Center.
She was born April 1, 1922, in Beallsville, daughter of the late Herbert W. and Esther (Brown) Garrett.
Mrs. Winland was a member of New Castle Church of Christ and retired from Barnesville Hospital, where she served in the housekeeping department.
She was preceded in death by her husband, Russell L. Winland; a son, Lewis Winland; and two brothers, Clarence and James Garrett.
She leaves three sons, Charles (Regina) Winland and Thomas (Martha) Winland, both of Jerusalem, and Bill Winland of Alledonia; three brothers, Thomas Garrett of Galion, John Garrett of Jacksonville, Fla., and Homer Garrett of Millersburg; three sisters, Dorothy Johnson of Cambridge, Margaret Louthen of Reynoldsburg and Martha McConnell of Barnesville; eight grandchildren and two great-grandchildren; several nieces and nephews.
Friends may call from 6 to 9 p.m. Thursday at Campbell-Plumly-Milburn Funeral Home, Barnesville, where services will be 1 p.m. Friday.
Burial will be in Crestview Cemetery, Barnesville.
 
 
Friday, September 16, 1927
Garrett, Wilfred and Alma Lumbatis
Announcements have been received of the marriage of Wilfred C. Garrett, eldest son of Mrs. Cleota Garrett of Summerfield route 3, and Miss Alma Lumbatis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sherman Lumbatis of Lewisville, which took place on Friday, September with Squire English of Woodsfield performing the ceremony. After a few days visit in Zanesville, they returned to the homes of their parents and when their marriage was announced, they were given a joy ride, seated on a box on an old truck, from the Garret home to Summerfield and back.
Both Mr. and Mrs. Garrett are fine young people and are now receiving the sincere good wishes of many friends.
Mr. Garrett recently received the appointment as rural mail carrier on Summerfield route 3 effective November 1, and he and his bride will establish their home here in the near future.
 
1973
Wilfred C. Garrett
Summerfield, OH- Wilfred C. Garrett, 70, of Summerfield, a retired mail carrier, died unexpectedly at 3:45 pm. Friday (April 6, 1973) at his home of an apparent heart attack.
A life resident of Sumemrfield, in Noble County, he was born September 24, 1902. A son of Emory and Emma E. Herlan Garrett. His first wife, the former Alma Lumbatis, died in 1961.
Mr. Garrett carried mail in the Summerfield area 41 years before retiring in 1969. He was a member of Summerfield United Methodist Church, Summerfield Lodge No. 452 F&AM, and the Retired Letter Carrier Association.
Survivors incLude his widow, the former Leora Backus; a daughter, Mrs. Thelma Schel of Canton; a son, Dale Garrett of Caldwell Route 1; two step-daughters, Mrs. Naomi Triplett of Heath and Mrs. Lois Alexander of Johnstown; four step-sons, David Backus with the U. S. Navy, John, Paul and Mark Backus, all of Columbus; five grandchildren and 17 step-grandchildren. Two brothers are deceased.
The body is at Brubach Funeral Home here and will be taken to the family home at 5 p.m. today where friends may call. Masonic services will be held at 7:30 pm. Sunday at the home.
Services will be held at 2 pm. Monday at Summerfield United Methodist Church conducted by Rev. Richard Smith. Burial will be in Eastern Cemetery here.

Gates, Duane
Source--Times Leader Martins Ferry, Ohio
Published--February 16, 2005
Gates , Duane "Andy" , 74, of Market Street, Clarington, died Monday, February 14, 2005 in Wetzel County Hospital. He was born on July 30, 1930 in Steinersville, the son of the late William and May Bonar Gates. He was a retired aluminum worker from the former Conalco Plant and a protestant by faith. In addition to his parents, he was preceded in death by a sister, Donna Jean Mays. Surviving are his wife, Patricia Butler Gates, three daughters, Stacey (Richard) Morgan of Tallahassee, Florida, Kelly Ann (Paul) Tilton of Maryland, and Lisa G. Madlin of Virginia; three grandchildren, Andrew Richard Morgan, a cadet of West Point, Casey B. and Copper S. Tilton, both of Maryland; two sisters, Nancy (Keith) Crawford of Sardis and Joyce Courtney of San Diego, California, several nieces and nephews. Family will receive friends on Thursday from 10 a.m until the time of service at 1 p.m., at Grisell Funeral Home, 125 Clarinda Drive, Clarington, with Pastor Donald Hicthcock and Reverend Wendy Erb officiating. Interment to follow in Clarington Cemetery, Clarington. Memorial contributions may be made to Immanuel United Church of Christ, 124 Shepherd Place, Clarington, Ohio 43915. Sympathy expressions to www.grisellfuneralhome.com.

Gatten, Alvina C.
Alvina Christina Gatten, aged 83 years, died at the home of her daughter, Mrs. W. S. NOLAN, at 826 Sherman Avenue at 12:50 p.m. today. She was born in Belmont County, Ohio, in 1826, and lived there the greater part of her life. Her husband, James R. Gatten who was a school teacher, died 13 years ago. Mrs. Gatten went to Carroll, Iowa, some years ago to live with a son, but when her health began to fail, she desired to return to Ohio, saying that she wished to spend her last days in the old Buckeye State. Mrs. Gatten came to this city last August. The infirmities of her advanced years crept on and she gradually weakened until her . Mrs. Gatten joined the Christian Church when she was 22 years of age. Her surviving children are Mrs. S. J. HUNT, of Barnesville, Ohio; Mrs. W. S. NOLAN, this city; Thomas and John Gatten of Carroll, Iowa; Lou Gatten of Kansas; Edward Gatten, of Barnesville, and Addison Gatten of St. Louis. She leaves 15 grandchildren and 8 great-grandchildren.
Source: Steubenville Weekly Gazette, Steubenville, Ohio, Friday, April 9, 1909
 
Gatten, Birdie Gatten
 
Dec 28, 1905
 
Apr 1983, residence: Woodsfield
Source: Monroe County death records
 
Source: The Marietta Times, dated Tuesday, February 3, 2004
Boyd G. Gatten
WOODSFIELD - Boyd G. Gatten, 72, of Conner Ridge Road died Sunday (Feb. 1, 2004) at Barnesville Hospital.
He was born Jan. 6, 1932, in Monroe County, Ohio, to Floyd D. Gatten and Birdie Gallagher Gatten. He had worked in the timber industry. He was a member of the Richfork Church of Christ.
 
He is survived by his twin brother, Lloyd Gatten and his wife, Mary Lou, of Woodsfield; two sisters, Bonnie McCaslin and her husband, Franklin, and Linda Lucas, both of Woodsfield; a special friend, Evelyn Daugherty of Woodsfield; one cousin, Naomi Smith of Woodsfield; and several nieces and nephews.
 
He was preceded in death by his parents; and one brother, Dale Jack Gatten Jr.
 
Services are at 1 p.m. Wednesday at Bauer-Turner Funeral Home at 100 S. Paul St., Woodsfield, with Harold Kinney officiating. Burial is in Oaklawn Cemetery at Woodsfield. Friends will be received from 6 to 9 p.m. today at the funeral home.
 
Gatten, Cecil E.
Source--Monroe County Beacon Woodsfield, Ohio
Published--January 14, 1965
Cecil E. Gatten, 53, of 1530 Walnut Street, Zanesville, Ohio, died Sunday evening, December 27, 1964, at 9:45 o'clock in Good Samaritan Hospital, Zanesville, where he had been admitted on Friday. He had been ill about six months.
Mr. Gatten was born May 13, 1911, in Woodsfield, a son of Oliver I. and Ethel E. Poulton Gatten, and had lived most of his life in Zanesville.
He was employed as a car loader for Dura Corporation.
Surviving are his mother, Mrs. Ethel Jones, of the home; one sister, Mrs. Jennie Louise Hook, of Zanesville; two brothers, Joseph B. Gatten and George Gatten of Zanesville, and several nieces and nephews,
His father and a brother, Harry, preceded him in death.
Funeral services were held Wednesday afternoon at 2:30 o'clock in Putnam Chapel of the Bolin Funeral Home in Zanesville,with Reverend Curtis Arnold officiating. Burial was in Greenwood Cemetery.
 
Gatten, Estella and Wilbert E. Willison
Wilbert E. Willison to Miss Stella Gatten wedding
Source: The Spirit of Democracy, Woodsfield, Ohio, dated, June 18,1914
On Saturday, June 6, 1914, was solemnized the marriage of Wilbert E. Willison to Miss Stella Gatten of Route two, Woodsfield, Ohio. The bride and groom are highly respected young people in the vicinity in which they live. Mr. Willison is the youngest son of Mr. and Mrs. David K. Willison. The wedding took place at Woodsfield, Ohio, after which a sumptuous supper was served at Mr. and Mrs. Winfield Gatten, the brides home. A number of the immediate relatives of the bride and groom were in attendance at this supper. Those from a distance were Mr. and Mrs. G.E. Stackhouse, son and daughter Wilton and Mamie of Ashland, Ohio, Mr. and Mrs. Otha Willison and son, Hallie of Barnesville, Ohio. Soon after supper was served, the fun makers arrived with sleigh bells, cow bells, circular saw and most anything that would make a noise and gave the couple a rousing serenade after which the groom treated the serenaders to cigars and candy. On Sunday an elegant dinner was served at the home of Mr. and Mrs. D.K. Willison. A number of the children and invited guests of the vicinity were present who joined in lightening the load under which the table fairly groaned. All present enjoyed the day immensely and when the party broke up, all went home wishing the happy couple a long and happy married life.
One Who was there
Gatten, Eva and Henry Paris
Henry Paris; age 26 on the 14 day of July 1903; born, Monroe County; occupation, farmer; father, McGovern Paris; license was issued on 15 day of September 1903, and married 16th day of September 1903, to Eva Gatten; age 21 on 5th day of May 1903; born, Graysville, Monroe County, Ohio; occupation, housekeeper; father, Mad. Doherty; married by Reverend J. Cooper.
Source: Monroe County marriage records
 
Gatten, Floyd, Mr. and Mrs.

DEC. 5, 1974

FIFTIETH ANNIVERSARY

Mr. and Mrs. Floyd Gatten

Source: The Monroe County Beacon, Woodsfield, Ohio

 

The children of Mr. and Mrs. Floyd Gatten honored their parents with a dinner in observance of their fiftieth wedding anniversary on Sunday, October twentieth.

Miss Birdie Gallagher, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Clem Gallagher, and Floyd Gatten, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Gatten, were married October 20, 1924. Mr. Gatten is now retired.

Mr. and Mrs. Gatten have five children, Lloyd Gatten, Boyd Gatten, Mrs. Frank (Bonnie) McCaslin, Mrs. Robert (Linda) Lucas, and one son

deceased.

Guests at the dinner included Mr. and Mrs. Floyd Gatten; Mr. and Mrs. Denver Abicht, daughter, Cathy, and friend, Terry Fencht, George Smith and Jeff Offenberger, of Marietta; Mr. and Mrs. George D. Bates, Mr. and Mrs. George L. Bates, son, Randy, and daughter, Tammy, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lucas and sons, Bobbie and Paul, Lloyd Gatten, Mr. and Mrs. Boyd Gatten, all of Woodsfield, Route 3; Mr. and Mrs. Frank McCaslin and sons, Eddie and Frankie. of Woods-field, Route 4; and Naomi Smith, of the home.

 
Gatten, Floyd Dale

March 17, 1988

The Monroe County Beacon, Woodsfield, Ohio

Floyd Gatten

Floyd D. Gatten, 82, of Route 3 Woodsfield, died March 13, 1988, at home. He was a former oil field worker, and Monroe County Highway Department employee. He was a member of the Richfork Church of Christ.

He was preceded in death by his wife Birdie Gallagher Gatten, in 1983; a son, Dale Jack Gatten, in 1951.

Surviving are two sons, Lloyd and Boyd, both of Woodsfield; two daughters, Bonnie McCaslin and Linda Lucas, both of Woodsfield; two sisters, Irene Stutz of Ashland, and Winona Adicht of Marietta; seven grandchildren; 12 great-grandchildren.

Friends were received at Bauer-Turner Funeral Home, Woodsfield. Interment in Oaklawn Cemetery, Woodsfield.

 
Gatten, Jean Kermit

Death

Marietta Times, Marietta, Ohio

January 1992

J. Kermit Gatten, former Lowell mayor

Lowell- J. Kermit Gatten, 63, of 189 Fourth St., a former mayor of Lowell, died Wednesday (Jan. 15, 1992) in Selby General Hospital.

Mr. Gatten had lived at Lowell since 1984 and had served as mayor from 1987 to 1991. He had retired as a professor of sociology at Marietta College. He had done his post graduate work at Ohio State University and had served on the Task Force on Prison Reform for Washington-Morgan Counties Community Action, where he had served as president of the board of directors. He also had been a federal employee serving as a sociologist with Housing and Urban Development.

Mr. Gatten was an Army veteran of the Korean War and had attended First Unitarian Universalist Church at Marietta. He received his bachelor s degree from Marietta College and his master s degree and doctorate degrees from Princeton University. He was a member of the Washington County Democratic Party, American Legion Post 70 at Lowell and Veterans of Foreign Wars Post 5108 at Marietta.

He was born Nov. 22, 1928, in Monroe County to Oliver T. Gatten and Audrey Highman Gatten Schafer.

In addition to his mother of Lewisville, Mr. Gatten is survived by his wife, Nan Piercy Gatten; one daughter, Gina Michelle Gatten at home a daughter and a son by a previous marriage, Joy Cowdery of Devola and Jeff Gatten of Kent; five grandchildren; two brothers, Kenneth of Enfield, Conn. and Delmas of Charleston, S.C.; and three sisters, Eula Kahrig and Sue Kuhn, both of Pataskala, and Amy Highman of High Point, N.C.

He was preceded in death by his father and one half-brother, William Muth.

Services will be at 10 a.m. Saturday in the Lowell Chapel of Cawley & Peoples Funeral Home with the Rev. Victor Cinson and Merle Farnsworth officiating. Burial will be in Oak Lawn Cemetery at Woodsfield with full military rites by American Legion Post 750 of Lowell. Friends may call from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. Friday at the funeral home.

Memorial contributions may be made to the L.S. Fire and Rescue Squad. Envelopes will be available at the funeral home.

 

 
Gatten, Murl E.
Source--Monroe County Beacon Woodsfield, Ohio
Published--Thursday May 6, 1999
Murl E. Gatten,83, died April 2, 1999. He was born in Graysville and lived 37 years in the Tallmage area. He worked as a machinist for Kent Machine and was a die maker for The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, retiring from Firestone in 1964. He was a member of The Chapel, where he served many years as the usher, served during World War II in the Army with the Military Police, serving in Europe and the Pacific, was Past Master of Akron Lodge 83 Free and Accepted Masons, was a member of Scottish Rite Valley of Akron. Tall Cedars of Lebanon, the Tadmor Shrine and the Tallmadge Grange.
Surviving are his wife of 50 years, LeDema Gatten; four sisters and three brothers-in-law, Helen Claus, of Akron, Mrs. Robert (Leora) Risen, of Logan, Mrs.Robert (Grethel) Durant, of Illinois, Mrs. Kenneth (Alma Mae) Cline of Clinton.
He was preceded in death by a sister, Eva Mayberry.
Friends were received April 4 at Hennessy-Bagnoli Funeral Home, Tallmadge, where services were held April 5, with Reverend Eloy Pacheco officiating. A graveside veteran service was conducted by Firestone Veterans of Foreign Wars Post 3383. Masonic Services were held April 4.
Memorial contributions may be made to The Chapel in University Park.
 
Gatten, Oliver I.

Gatten, Sarah Jane and Andrew J. Allen X

Source: Monroe County marriage records
 
Gatten, Thomas
Thomas H. Gatten, Jr., 61, of Village Lane, Jasper, Tennessee died Monday, March 29, 2004 at his home. He was born Dec. 18, 1942 at Washington, Pa., a son of the late Thomas H. and Alice Butterfield Gatten Sr.
Tom was a dispatcher for M.T.L. Trucking of Chattanooga, Tenn., a member of the North Terrace Church of Christ and a US Navy Veteran.
In addition to his parents he was preceded in death by a daughter, Mary Alice Gatten and two grandsons.
Surviving are his wife, Patricia Hammond Gatten, of Jasper; a daughter, Emma Lee Moore, of Martins Ferry; four sons William Frank Gatten and Thomas H. Gatten III, both of Wheeling, W. Va.; R. D. Ramsey of Dilles Bottom, Ohio and Dean "Pete" Ramsey of Bellaire, Ohio; a brother, William Gatten, of Waynesboro, Pa.; two sisters, Barbara Ruth Fulton and Virginia "Ginny" Gatten, both of Shadyside, Ohio; five grand- children; his step-mother, Wilma Kestner Gatten of Wheeling; two step- brothers, Harold and Donald Kestner, both of Moundsville, W. Va.; two stepsisters, Margaret Fallova, of Benwood, W. Va., and Betty Whitlatch of Wind Ridge, Pennsylvania. Friends will be received on Friday from 2 to 4 p.m. and 6 to 8 p.m. at Bauknecht-Altmeyer Funeral Homes & Crematory, 3900 Central Ave., Shadyside, Ohio, where services will be held Saturday at 11 a.m. with Minister Perry Hurst officiating. Burial follows in Powhatan Cemetery, Powhatan Point, Ohio.
Memorial contributions may be made to Esophagus Cancer Research.
 
 
Gatten, Tony Allen

January 31, 1973

GRADUATION

Tony A. Gatten

Source: The Spectator, Columbus, Ohio

Airman Tony A. Gatten, son of Mr. and Mrs. Delmas L. Gatten, 618 D'Lyn Street, has graduated at Keesler AFB. Miss., from the U.S. air force personnel specialist course conducted by the Air Training Command.

The Airman, is being assigned to Lackland AFB Texas, for duty with a unit of the Air Training Command.

Airman Gatten, whose wife is the former Carol J. Thompson, is a 1971 graduate of Westland High School, Galloway, Ohio.

Davis; license was issued 29 day of September 1903, and married 3rd day of October 1903, to Della P. Gatts, Lloyd Q. "Jack"
July 20th, 2004
Gatts, Lloyd Q. Jack , age 82 of RD#2, Graysville, West Virginia, died Tuesday, July 20, 2004 in Reynolds Memorial Hospital.
He was born December 7, 1921 in Moundsville, West Virginia, the son of the late Harley and Elizabeth Cresap Gatts.
He was a WWII Army Veteran, having served as Staff Sergeant in the South Pacific, a retired employee from Allied Chemical and a member of Graysville United Methodist Church.
In addition to his parents, he was preceded in death by two brothers, Richard and William Gatts.
Survivors include his loving wife of 62 years, Mary Wolfe Gatts a daughter, Lois (Edward) Zwolensky of Moundsville, West Virginia, a son, Richard Gatts of Limestone, West Virginia, three grandchildren, Doctor Brett Zwolensky of Clarksburg, Richard Gatts and Nicole Gatts, both of Limestone, a sister, Cecelia (Edward) Armour of Palm Coast, Florida and several dearly loved nieces and nephews.
Family will receive friends on Friday from 2-4 and 7-9pm at Grisell Funeral Home & Crematory, 400 Jefferson Avenue, Moundsville where funeral services will be held on Saturday at 1:30pm with Reverend Robert Milliren officiating. Interment in Graysville Cemetery, Proctor, West Virginia. Source--Grisell Funeral Home--On Line Obituaries

Geldmacher, Glenn
Born: January 25, 1912, died: January 1969, residence: Lewisville
Source: Monroe County death records
Geldmacher, Glenn G.
Source--News Clipping
Published-- January 1968
LEWISVILLE-- Glenn G. Geldmacher, 56, of Lewisville died at 5 a.m. Saturday, January 18,1968 at Marietta Memorial Hospital following a long illness.
Born January 25, 1912, in Lewisville, he was the son of William and Minnie Yoe Geldmacher.
He was a mechanic and welder by trade and a member of Trinity United Church of Christ, Masonic Lodge in Stafford, Scottish Rite of Cambridge.
Surviving are his widow, Lola Schockling Geldmacher; a son, Glenn Gayle of the home; a daughter, Mrs. Myron (Yolanda) Cline of Burgoon near Cleveland; a step-daughter, Mrs. Kay Whittacre of Graysville; four sisters, Mrs. Mabel Hankinson of Galloway, Mrs. Irene Young of near Lewisville, Mrs. Wilma (Thurman) Christman of near Woodsfield and Mrs. Melba Strouse of Saint Louis, Missouri; two brothers Fred of Cleveland and Raymond of Grantville, Utah; three grandchildren.
Friends may call at Bauer-Turner Funeral Home in Woodsfield.
Services will be held at 2 p.m. Tuesday at the funeral home with Reverend Wilmer Grunwald officiating. Burial will be in Friendship Cemetery in Lewisville.
 
Mrs. Minnie Geldmacher
Published--- October , 1959
provided by Betty Lendon Matson
Mrs. Minnie Geldmacher, age 79, of Lewisville, Route 1, passed away in Marietta Memorial Hospital on Tuesday afternoon, October 13, 1959, where she had been a patient for one week.
A daughter of the late Aaron and Jane McCammon Yoe, she was born near Lewisville, May 9, 1880.
Surviving are four daughters, Mrs. Mabel Hankinson, of Galloway, Ohio; Mrs. Irene Young, of Lewisville, Route 1; Mrs. Wilma Christman, of Jerusalem, Route 1, and Mrs. Melba Stause, of St. Louis, Missouri; three sons, Frederick Geldmacher, of Cleveland;
Raymond Geldmacher, of Grantsville, Utah, and Glenn Geldmacher, of Lewisville; twenty grandchildren; six great grandchildren; one sister, Mrs. Estella Calvert, of Columbus, and one brother, Junior Yoe, of Belmont.
Her husband, W. H. Geldmacher, preceded her in death in January ,1934.
Friends are being received at The Bauer and Turner Funeral Home.
Brief services will be held in their chapel Friday afternoon at 1:30 o'clock E.S.T., with
additional services at St. John's Evangelical and Reformed Church, (Middle Church),
at 2:00 o'clock E.S.T. Rev. George Varnes will officiate. Interment will be in the church cemetery.
 
Geldmacher, Raymond William

March 5, 1987

The Monroe County Beacon, Woodsfield, Ohio

Raymond Geldmacher

Raymond William Geldmacher, 77, of Grantsville, UT, died Feb. 17 at Tooele Valley Nursing Home following a short illness. He was born Nov. 25, 1909 in Lewisville, to William and Minnie Geldmacher.

He was a graduate of Lewisville High School.

On Dec. 16, 1933 he married Virginia Worthington. The couple was married for 53 years.

Mr. Geldmacher was a member of the Grantsville Volunteer Fire Department and the Lions Club. He served two terms on the city council and in 1969 he was selected as Man of the Year for Grantsville City. During his retirement years, he served several years as a Name Extraction Missionary and as a temple worker.

He worked 15 yeas on the railroad before he went into business as a merchant. He operated the G & H Store in Grantsville for 30 years.

Surviving are his wife, Virginia; four children, Gary of San Diego, CA, Shirley Maxwell of Bountiful, UT, David of Brigham City, UT; and Sam of Mona, UT. He is also survived by four sisters, Wilma, Irene, Melba and Mabel; and one brother, Frederick.

He was preceded in death by one son, Charles, of Grantsville.

Services were held Feb. 20 at Grantsville L.D.S. West Stake Center. Burial in Grantsville City Cemetery.

Gertler, Mrs. Lura and Mr. Ralph F. Lower
Source:The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., August 24, 1916
Mr. Ralph F. LOWER of near Youngstown, Ohio and Mrs. Lura GERTLER of this city were united in marriage at the home of the bride on Eastern Avenue Tuesday afternoon at 2 o clock. The Reverend R. L. RYALL performed the ceremony.
 
Gertler, Philip
Philip Gertler Dies at Ozark
Source:TheSpirit of Democracy, dated, September 1942
Provided by Lena Kahrig Pettit, typed by Betty Lendon Matson
Phillip W. Gertler, aged 75 years, passed away at his home at Ozark at 3:30 o'clock this Thursday morning, September 10, 1942. He had suffered a paralytic stroke on last Thursday morning.
Surviving are his wife; one daughter, Mrs. Newell Paine, of the home; two grandsons, Larry William and Frank Gertler Paine, also of the home; one brother, George Gertler, Woodsfield, and one sister, Mrs. Elizabeth Moore of Ozark.
Short funeral services at the home Saturday afternoon will be followed by final rites at St. Paul's Evangelical and Reformed Church in Woodsfield, at 2:00 o'clock. Rev. John H. Hose will be in charge of the services and burial will be made in Oaklawn Cemetery.
Mr. Gertler was a member of St. Paul's Church and a member of Jerusalem K. of P. Lodge.

Giles, Jean W.
Source:STATESMAN JOURNAL, SALEM, OREGON
Provided by Betty Lendon Matson
April 1, 1923 March 19, 2001
Jean Giles, 77, of Salem died Monday. (MARION CO.)
She was born in Fly, (MONROE CO.)Ohio, and moved to Columbus,(Franklin CO.) Ohio, in 1941 and to Salem in 1994. She retired as office manager from Columbus Public Schools in 1984. She was a member of Veterans of Foreign Wars Auxiliary, South Salem Senior Citizens and Skyline Baptist Church. She enjoyed writing. She married Clarence in 1946; he is deceased.
Survivors include her daughter, Colette Tennant of Salem; and three grandchildren.
Visiting will be 3 to 7 p.m. Thursday at Virgil T. Golden Chapel. Services will be Monday at Rutherford-Corbin Chapel, Worthington, Ohio. Interment will be at Union Cemetery, Columbus. Contributions: Habitat for Humanity, 680 State St., Salem, OR 97301.

Gillispie, George L. Gillispie
 
 
January 30, 1920
 
 
Gillman, Mattie
 
 
March 14, 1914
 
Gillogly, Betty Lou Ault X
Betty Lou Ault, 72, of Cambridge, died Friday (July 16, 2004) at Cambridge Health and Rehabilitation Center. She was born January 7, 1932, in New Concord, daughter of the late Ross Gillogly and Irene Myers Gillogly.
Mrs. Ault retired from the former March Electric Plant, where she served 29 years. She was a 1950 graduate of New Concord High School. She was a member of Stop Nine Church of Christ and Golden Sixties. She enjoyed writing poetry and was actively involved in Scouting. She collected owls and loved photography.
She was preceded in death by two brothers, Ian and Jerry; and a sister, Jean Hogue. She leaves her husband, Bob Ault of Woodsfield, whom she married July 19, 1975; two sons, David (Mary) Clifton of Claysville and Chuck Clifton of Cambridge; two stepsons, Bradley (Sandy) Ault of Wasilla, Alaska, and Doug (Denise) Ault of Anchorage, Alaska; a foster son, Doug Hawkins of Columbus; two daughters, Mrs. Marty (Debbie) Price of Cambridge and Bunny Whittle of Claysville; a stepdaughter, Mrs. Steve (Marla) Miller of Ellenton, Fla.; three sisters, Shirley McAvoy of Zanesville, Patricia Anderson of Kissimmee, Fla., and Mrs. Don (Mary) Hivaor of McConnelsville; a half-sister, Mrs. Dave (Connie) Ellenberg of Alabama; and a host of friends, including a special friend, Gleneda Powers.
Friends may call from 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 p.m. Monday at Thorn-Black Funeral Home, Cambridge, where services will be 11 a.m. Tuesday. Burial will be in Guernsey Memory Gardens. Source: The Daily Jeffersonian, July 18, 2004
 
 
Gilmore, Atha M. Hashman
BARNESVILLE--Atha M. Hashman, nee Gilmore, 98, of Barnesville, died Tuesday evening (January. 14, 1986) at her residence.
She was born October. 5, 1887, in Monroe County, daughter of the late Vincent and Mary Gilmore. Mrs. Hashman was a member of First Christian Church in Barnesville.
She was preceded in death by her husband, Scott, one son and one daughter.
She leaves a son, Fred Hashman, of Barnesville; a sister, Mrs. Victor Long of Bailey's Mills; several grandchildren, great-grandchildren and great-great-grandchildren.
Friends may call from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 P.M. Thursday at Campbell-Plumly Funeral Home in Barnesville, where services will be at 11 A.M. Friday with Rev. William Worcester officiating. Burial will be in Crestview Cemetery. Wed. 15 July 1986 Jeffersonian.

Switzerland twp.
 
 
GLASSER, Sylvester Nicholas
Sylvester Nicholas GLASSER, a native of Woodsfield, but recently of St. Francis hospital in Columbus, Ohio, died at the home of his brother-in-law, Charles REASBECK of Martins Ferry, Ohio. February 16, 1916. He arrived in Martins Ferry one week ago on a visit, and taking ill, succumbed to a complication of troubles. Deceased was single and was 47 years of age. Funeral services were held Friday morning at St. Mary s Church, Martins Ferry, and interment at Bellaire. Mr. Glasser leaves to mourn his , father John GLASSER, Sr., five brothers, Joseph, John, Leo, Charles GLASSER of Bellaire, Jacob GLASSER of Charlerol, Pennsylvania, and three sisters, Mrs. Charles SCHUMACHER of Woodsfield, Mrs. Charles REASBECK of Martins Ferry, and Sister Angeline of Rochester, Minnesota.
Source:The Spirit of Democracy, Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, February 24, 1916

Goldinger, Robert T. Goldinger
 
 
1933
 
Good, Linwood Source--Times Leader Martins Ferry, Ohio Published--September 22, 2004
 
Good, Linwood Arnold , 76, of 247 Belt Street, Powhatan Point, Ohio, died Thursday, Sept. 16, 2004 at the Shadyside Care Center, Shadyside, Ohio. He was born November 17, 1927 in Bangor Maine, a son of the late Arnold and Eva Gilman Good. He was a full time volunteer minister at the Kingdom Hall of Jehovah's Witnesses in Powhatan Point, Ohio. Surviving is his wife, Pauline G. Perkins Good. A Memorial service will be held, 11 a.m., Saturday, Sept. 25, 2004 in the Kingdom Hall of Jehovah's Witnesses, 155 Clark Street, Powhatan Point, Ohio, with Speaker Craig Pevarski officiating. Burial will be in Mt. Hope Cemetery Bangor, Maine, at the convenience of the family. Funeral arrangements by Bauknecht-Altmeyer Funeral Homes and Crematory, 186 Main Street, Powhatan Point, Ohio. Memorial contributions may be made to the Kingdom Hall of Jehovah's Witnesses, Powhatan Point, Ohio 43942

Goodhart, John Franklin

In Memory of John Franklin Goodhart, born September 29, 1909; died April 23, 1995. Services by Bundy-Law Funeral Home, Tuesday, April 25, 1995, 11 a.m., Clergy Evang. Myron Builer, Interment at Calais Cemetery, Calais, Ohio, arrangements by Bundy-Law Funeral Home. Source: Memory card

 

 
Goodhart, Mary L.

August 3, 1972

DEATH

Mary L. Goodhart (nee Rubel)

Source: Beacon

Mrs. Mary L. Goodhart, 96 of Vel Haven Nursing Home, Cambridge former Summerfield area resident, died Saturday morning, July 29, 1972, at 6:20 o'clock in Guernsey Memorial Hospital at Cambridge, following an illness.

Born in Monroe County, September 26, 1875, she was a daughter of the late Jacob and Barbara Pfalzgraf Rubel.

Mrs. Goodhart leaves one son, John Goodhart, of Cambridge. Her husband William Goodhart, died in 1943.

Funeral services were held Monday afternoon at two o'clock in the Calais United Methodist Church, with the Rev. Myron Guiler officiating. Burial was in the Calais Cemetery with the Brubach Funeral Home of Summerfield in charge.

 
 
Goodwin, (Stillborn)
Died: June 30, 1913
 
Gorby, John
Source--Wetzel Message Board West Virginia
Published--(No Date)
John Gorby, 80, of Rt. 1 Proctor died Tuesday, October 17, in Reynolds Memorial Hospital. He
was born in Pine Grove, West Virginia November 18, 1919 the son of the late George and Martha
Shreve Gorby. He was a retired farmer and an employee of Ormet,Hannibal, Ohio. An Army veteran of
World War II and a member of Antioch and Proctor Christian Churches. In addition to his parents
he was preceded in death by his wife May Blake Gorby; seven brothers, homer, Clarence,
Walter, Rolle, Jim, Efrim, and Russell Gorby; a sister Amanda Credal. Surviving are a
daughter, Sharon Midcap of Proctor; two grandchildren, Danny McKinney and his wife Jill,
of New Martinsville and Mrs, Phillip (Rebecca) Voight of Proctor. Three great
grandchildren, Charis, Carvea and Trueet Voight, all of Proctor; and a sister Amelia Melcher
of Beech Bottom. Grisell Funeral Home in New Martinsville handled arrangements,
Interment at Antioch Cemetery.
 
 
Gorby, Kenneth H.
 
August 5, 1942
 
May 2, 1996
 
Clarington
 
Gorby, Schuster, Mary Ann, nee Gorby
Source--Times Leader Martins Ferry, Ohio
Published--December 2002
Mary Ann Gorby Schuster, 58, of Powhatan Point, Ohio went to be with the Lord on Monday, Dec. 30, 2002 at the Ohio Valley Medical Center in Wheeling. She was born Aug. 20, 1944 in Glen Dale, W.Va. a daughter of the late James Ephirm and Clara Virginia Farmer Gorby.
Mary Ann was the owner of Schuster Upholstery and Antiques in Powhatan Point. She attended the First United Methodist Church in Powhatan Point and was a member of the Powhatan Improvement Committee.
In addition to her parents, she was preceded in death by two sisters, Barbara Louise Alexander and Nancy Cleo Greathouse.
Surviving are her husband, George Watson Schuster; three daughters, Belinda Austen and her husband, Michael of Powhatan Point, Ohio, Francis Psciuk of Orlando, Fla. and Tammy Hochstrasser and her husband, Clyde of New Martinsville, W.Va.; two sons, George Schuster and his wife, Alicia of Bridgeport, Ohio and Bruce Schuster and his wife Jennifer of Belmont, Ohio; three sisters, Margaret Gower and Betty Hahn both of Moundsville, W.Va. and Linda Parsons of French Creek, W.Va. Also four grandchildren, Kayla and Koty Schuster, Jesse Clark and Savannah Austen.
Friends will be received at the Bauknecht-Altmeyer Funeral Home, 186 Main Street, Powhatan Point on Wednesday from 2 to 4 and 6 to 8 p.m. and Thursday from 11 a.m. until time of services at 1 p.m. with the Reverend Theresa Bobot officiating. Interment in the Powhatan Cemetery, Powhatan Point, Ohio.
Memorial contributions may be made to the First United Methodist Church, 169 Main Street, Powhatan Point, Ohio 43942 or the Powhatan Improvement Committee in care of Carolyn Rutter, 145 Main Street, Powhatan Point, Ohio 43942.

Graeb, John O. Graeb
 
December 27, 1903
 
August 20, 1988
 
Woodsfield
Wilbert E. Willison to Miss Stella Gatten wedding
Source: The Spirit of Democracy, Woodsfield, Ohio, dated, June 18,1914
On Saturday, June 6, 1914, was solemnized the marriage of Wilbert E. Willison to Miss Stella Gatten of Route two, Woodsfield, Ohio. The bride and groom are highly respected young people in the vicinity in which they live. Mr. Willison is the youngest son of Mr. and Mrs. David K. Willison. The wedding took place at Woodsfield, Ohio, after which a sumptuous supper was served at Mr. and Mrs. Winfield Gatten, the brides home. A number of the immediate relatives of the bride and groom were in attendance at this supper. Those from a distance were Mr. and Mrs. G.E. Stackhouse, son and daughter Wilton and Mamie of Ashland, Ohio, Mr. and Mrs. Otha Willison and son, Hallie of Barnesville, Ohio. Soon after supper was served, the fun makers arrived with sleigh bells, cow bells, circular saw and most anything that would make a noise and gave the couple a rousing serenade after which the groom treated the serenaders to cigars and candy. On Sunday an elegant dinner was served at the home of Mr. and Mrs. D.K. Willison. A number of the children and invited guests of the vicinity were present who joined in lightening the load under which the table fairly groaned. All present enjoyed the day immensely and when the party broke up, all went home wishing the happy couple a Long and happy married life.
One Who was there

Graham, Jack A.
 
September 19, 1932
 
October 28, 1993, residence: Lewisville
 
Graham, Orris Gail 'Jobie'
WOODSFIELD - Orris Gail "Jobie" Graham, 97, of Woodsfield, Ohio, died Wednesday (Dec. 22, 2004) at the Woodsfield Nursing & Rehabilitation Center where he had been a resident since Sept. 3, 2003.
He was born July 30, 1907, in Bloomfield, Washington County, a son of the late John Furl (Eber) Graham and Minnie Day Graham.
He attended Marietta College, was an independent oil and gas producer, enjoyed working with motors in his shop and was an avid reader. He lived in Bloomfield before moving to Woodsfield in 1948.
He was a member of the Muskingum Valley Baptist Church on Tice Run Road near Bloomfield. He also was a member of the Veterans of Foreign Wars 5303, Eagles Lodge 2302, Moose Lodge 2247, and Monroe Lodge 189 Free and Accepted Masons, all of Woodsfield, the Ancient Accepted Scottish Rite Valley and the Alladin Shrine Tempole AAONMS of Columbus.
He was preceded in death by his wife, Floris Holland Graham whom he married April 27, 1929; one daughter, Jean Collin and her husband, John; two sons, Eber Graham and Jack Graham and his wife, Ruth; one grandson, Max Graham; one sister, Hazel Graham Edwards and her husband, Ben; two brothers, Wayne Graham and his wife, Marguerite; and an infant brother. He was the last surviving member of a family of four.
He is survived by two daughters, Dawn Nye and her husband, Joe, of New Matamoras and Joan Hines and her husband, Jim, of Graysville; one son, Gary Graham and his wife, Joy, of Smithville, Ohio; one daughter-in-law, Marcella Graham of Walhonding, Ohio; 17 grandchildren; six stepgrandchildren; 27 great-grandchildren; 14 stepgreat-grandchildren; seven great-great-grandchildren; three stepgreat-great-grandchildren; two nephews, Dan Graham of Marietta and Dick Graham of Cape Coral, Fla.; two nieces, Susan Rinard of Marietta and Patty Chalfam of Cape Coral, Fla.; one sister-in-law, Buena "Jo" Holland Jackman of Zanesville; and countless friends.
Friends will be received from 2 to 9 p.m. Monday (Dec. 27) at the Bauer-Turner Funeral Home, 100 S. Paul St., Woodsfield, Ohio. Friends will also be received from noon until the time of the funeral services at 1 p.m. Tuesday (Dec. 28) at the Muskingum Valley Baptist Church, Tice Run Road near Bloomfield, with the Rev. Gale Lauderman officiating. Burial will be in the church cemetery.
Masoic lodge services will be held at 7 p.m. Monday at the funeral home.
Memorial contributions may be made to the Muskingum Valley Baptist Church, in care of Birdie Kroll, 133 SR 260, Rinard Mills, Ohio 45734.
 
Graham, Raymond
Source--The Times Leader Martins Ferry, Ohio
Published--September 7, 2004
Raymond R.Graham, 70, of Bethesda, died Sunday, Sept. 5, 2004 at OVMC Wheeling, W. Va. He was born Dec. 12, 1933 in Armstrongs Mills, a son of the late George and Goldie Willison Graham. Ray was retired from North American Coal Mine #3, he services as a special deputy with the Belmont County Sheriffs Dept., and was a 26 year member of the Belmont County Fair Board, and was also active in area saddle clubs.In addition to his parents, he was preceded in death by a sister and three brothers. Surviving are his wife, Mildred (Sis) Eden Graham; two daughters, Kathy Hart and Patti Schultz, both of Bethesda; two sons, Roger of Morristown, and Ray of Beallsville; his mother-in-law, Thelma Kemp, of Bethesda, 11 grand children, nine great-grandchildren, several step grand and great grandchildren; two sisters, Alice Perkins of Beallsville and Gladys Tomlinson of St. Clairsville; three brothers, Clyde of Columbus, George of Powhatan, and John of Barnesville. Friends will be received Wednesday 4 to 8 p.m. at Kelly-Kemp-Braido Funeral Home, 322 North Main St., Bethesda, where services will be held Thursday at 11 a.m. Burial in Ebenezer Cemetery, Bethesda, Ohio
 
Graham, Stuart and Miss Martha Jane Highman
Graham-Highman Marriage Solemnized
Source: The Monroe County Beacon, dated, Monday, August 23, 1948
 
At 11:30 o'clock Friday morning July 30th, Miss Martha Jane Highman,
daughter of Mr.and Mrs. D. E. Highman, of Woodsfield, Route 2, and Mr. Stuart Ralph Graham, son of Mr. and Mrs. D. E. Graham, also of Woodsfield, Route 2 were united in marriage.
 
The single ring ceremony was read by Rev. O. O. Wilson at his home in Caldwell, Ohio.
 
The bride was attired in a street length dress of teal blue crepe with which she wore white a white accessories. Her corsage was of pale pink carnations.
 
Miss Betty Graham, sister of the groom, attended as maid of honor. She wore a shell pink dress with white accessories. Her corsage was also of pale pink carnations.
 
The groom wore a gray pinstriped suit and a pink carnation in his lapel. Mr. Bill Graham served his brother as best man. He wore a brown suit with a pink carnation in his lapel.
 
The bride attended The Woodsfield High School. Mr. Graham attended Graysville High School and served three years in The US Army.
 
The happy young couple are now making their home with the bride's parents. Their many friends extend congratulations and best wishes.
 
Graham, William "Billy Ray" R.
Source:Marietta Times . . Marietta, OH . . Feb 2002
Woodsfield - William R. "Billy Ray" Graham, 48, of 215 1/2 S. Paul St. died at 3:28 a.m. Wednesday (February 13, 2002) at Ohio State University Hospital in Columbus.
He was born June 19, 1953, in Cambridge to Pastor William G. and Wanda King Graham. He had attended the Church of the Nazarene in Woodsfield.
He is survived by two daughters, Stephanie Goddard and her husband, Michael, of Sardis, and Tiffany Rene Graham of Stark County, Ohio; his parents; two brothers, David Graham and his wife, Cindy, and Randy Graham and his wife, Tammy, both of Woodsfield; two grandsons, Jesse Goddard and Jacob Goddard, both of Sardis; three nieces; and two nephews.
Services are at 11 a.m. Saturday at Watters Funeral Home in Woodsfield with Pastor David Langdon officiating. Burial is in Oaklawn Cemetery in Woodsfield. Friends will be received from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. today at the funeral home.
Source: The Marietta Times, Friday, December 24, 2004.
 
Gramlich, Charles T. and Miss Anna Ackerman
Miss Anna Ackerman daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Conrad Ackerman, and Mr. Charles C. Gramlich, were married in Woodsfield last Saturday by Rev. George L. Davis, pastor of the M. E. Church. The bride is a very highly respected young lady of Woodsfield, and the groom is employed in the railroad business at Zanesville, where the happy couple are now located in a home previously furnished for them.
Source: The Spirit of Democracy, Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, October 25, 1923.
 
Gramlich, Clay
Born: October 3, 1892
August 1966
Jerusalem
 
Grandi, August and Mildred Keiser

Mr. and Mrs. August Grandi of Route 1, Jerusalem, will be honored on their 50th wedding anniversary with an open house hosted by their family.

The celebration will be held June 29, from 2 until 5 p.m. followed by a dance from 7 until 10 p.m. in the Somerton Fire House in Somerton.

August Grandi of New Philadelphia and the former Mildred Keiser of Somerton were united in marriage June 27, 1936 by the Reverend May LaFolletti in the Somerton Parsonage. They are the parents of four daughters: Mrs. Karl (Linda) Reichmann of Quaker City, Mrs. Rodney (Betty) Kahrig of Route 3, Woodsfield, Mrs. Ray (Mary) Carpenter of Batesville, and Mrs. Paul (Esther) Riley of Route 1, Senecaville. Four grandchildren, Chip and Kevin Jones, Kristal Kahrig and Jamie Riley, complete the family circle.

Family and friends are welcome to attend the open house and dance. The couple requests that gifts be omitted.

Source: June 19, 1986, The Monroe County Beacon, Woodsfield, Ohio, p. 5

 

Source: The Daily Jeffersonian, Cambridge, Ohio, Thursday, February 29, 2003X
August L. 'Gus' Grandi
BARNESVILLE August L. Gus Grandi, 91, of Betts Road, Jerusalem, died Wednesday (Feb. 26, 2003) at Woodsfield Nursing and Rehabilitation Center.
 
Friends may call from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. Friday at Kelly-Kemp-Braido Funeral Home, Barnesville, where services will be 1 p.m. Saturday with Pastor Rusty Atkinson officiating.
 
Burial will be in Boston Cemetery.
 
Memorial contributions may be made to Somerset Township Community Park, c/o Diane Blattler, 56783 Somerton Highway, Barnesville, OH 43713, or the Somerton Volunteer Fire Department, c/o Steve Wharton, Somerton Route, Barnesville, OH 43713.

 

 
Grandi, Betty Lou and Rodney Ellis Kahrig
Mr. and Mrs. August L. Grandi request the honour of your presence at the marriage of their daughter Betty Lou Grandi to Mr. Rodney Ellis Kahrig, on Sunday, the ninth of June nineteen hundred and sixty-eight at two o'clock at the Church of Christ, Woodsfield, Ohio. Source: Wedding Invitation.
 
Source: The Times Leader, martins ferry, Ohio, dated Tuesday, April 15, 2003
Mildred Grandi, nee Keiser
Mildred Alice Grandi, 84, of Jerusalem, Ohio, died Sunday, April 13, 2003, at Barnesville Hospital. She was born April 20, 1918 in Bolivar, Ohio, a daughter of the late Walter Scott Keiser and Myrtle Iona Stephan Keiser.
Mildred worked many years with her husband, Gus, in the family business, Grandi Trucking, she loved baking, quilting and embroidery, and was a Methodist by faith.
 
In addition to her parents, she was preceded in death by her husband, August (Gus) Grandi, three infant children, Joan, Melva Louise and Melvin Louis Grandi; five sisters, Florence McFeeders, Melva Conklin, Ethel Lorenz, Dorothy McConaughy and Glenda Inherst; brothers, Kenneth Keiser, Virgil Keiser, and Mildred Keiser.
 
Surviving are four daughters, Mrs. Karl (Linda) Reischman, of Quaker City, Mrs. Rodney (Betty) Kahrig of Woodsfield, Mrs. Ray (Mary) Carpenter of Batesville, and Mrs. Paul (Esther) Riley of Senecaville; four grandchildren, Petty Officer, Charles (Chip) Jones II of Hawaii, Kevin Louis Jones of Cambridge, Kristal Kahrig of Woodsfield, and Jamie Alice Riley of Senecaville; one sister, Geraldine Miller of Barnesville, several nieces and nephews.
 
Friends will be received Wednesday from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. at Kelly-Kemp-Braido Funeral Home, 702 East Main St., Barnesville, where services will be held Thursday at 11 a.m., with Pastor Rusty Atkinson officiating. Burial follow in Boston Cemetery.
 
Memorial contributions to the Somerset Twp. Community Park, c/o Diane Blattler, 56783 Somerton Highway, Barnesville, Ohio 43713, or the Somerton VFD, c/o Steve Wharton Somerton Rt., Barnesville, Ohio 43713.

The Marietta Times, Saturday, March 1, 2003
Beulah L. Lumbatis, nee Gray
LEWISVILLE - Beulah L. Lumbatis, 84, of 46007 Ohio 145, Lewisville, died Friday (Feb. 28, 2003) at her home.
She was born Aug. 9, 1918, near Lewisville to Emma Denbow Winland and Roy Gray. She was a homemaker and was a Protestant by faith.
 
She is survived by two daughters, Jeanie Roe and her husband, Dellano, and Marlene Crum, all of Lewisville; two sons, Richard Lumbatis and his wife, Janice, and Gale Lumbatis and his wife, Angel, all of Lewisville; three sisters, Lorna Jones of Lewisville, Delores McGarry of Lewisville and Loretta Rinard of Woodsfield; one brother, Lloyd Eugene Winland; 14 grandchildren; 20 great-grandchildren; several step grandchildren; and several step great-grandchildren.
 
She was preceded in death by her husband, Jacob Ward "Bodie" Lumbatis, on Oct. 17, 1991; one son, David Lumbatis; her parents; two brothers, Harold Winland and Francis "Spark" Winland; and one grandson, Mark Aaron Lumbatis.
 
Services and burial will be held at the convenience of the family. Friends will be received from 2 to 9 p.m. Sunday at Watters Funeral Home in Woodsfield.

Source: The Marietta Times, Wednesday, Sept, 24, 2003
Frances A. Steed Gray
 
WOODSFIELD - Frances A. Steed Gray, 96, of the Woodsfield Nursing and Rehabilitation Center in Woodsfield died Monday (Sept. 22, 2003) at the care center.
She was born Nov. 16, 1907, in Monroe County to Sanford and Clara Kysor Steed.
 
She is survived by one daughter, Virginia Sheba of Powhatan Point; two sisters, Lorraine Steed of Woodsfield and Elizabeth McCollum of Canton; 12 grandchildren; 23 great-grandchildren; and nine great-great-grandchildren.
 
She was preceded in death by her husband, Dorsey Gray; two daughters, Mary C. Hill and Edna M. Gray; her parents; one brother; and three sisters.
 
Services are at 1 p.m. Friday at Bauer-Turner Funeral Home, 100 S. Paul St., Woodsfield, with Minister Jeremy Joy officiating. Burial is in Oaklawn Cemetery in Woodsfield. Friends will be received from 3 to 5 and 7 to 9 p.m. Thursday at the funeral home.

Gray, James M.
Rites Held Sunday
Source:The Spirit of Democracy, dated, October 15, 1942
Provided by Lena Kahrig Pettit, typed by Betty Lendon Matson
James M. Gray, aged eighty years, passed away last Friday afternoon at four o'clock, at his home, west of Woodsfield, on the Woodsfield and Lewisville road. He had been ill for several years and serious for a few weeks.
He is survived by his widow and one daughter, Miss Mary of the home besides many other relatives and friends.
Funeral services were held on Sunday afternoon at 2:00 o'clock at the late home, with Rev. Theodore Peterson officiating. Burial was made in The Oaklawn Cemetery with W. P. Galbraith in charge.
Mr. Gray was a self-reliant industrious citizen, honorable and friendly in all his relations with others. As a business man, both in a store near Graysville and in a retail feed business, near his late home, he enjoyed the high confidence of his patrons.
Mr. Gray was a member of The Methodist Church but for the past several years was prevented by illness from attendance at church services.
typed by betty lendon matson

Source: The Monroe County Beacon, dated, Monday, August 23, 1948
 
At 11:30 o'clock Friday morning July 30th, Miss Martha Jane Highman,
daughter of Mr.and Mrs. D. E. Highman, of Woodsfield, Route 2, and Mr. Stuart Ralph Graham, son of Mr. and Mrs. D. E. Graham, also of Woodsfield, Route 2 were united in marriage.
 
The single ring ceremony was read by Rev. O. O. Wilson at his home in Caldwell, Ohio.
 
The bride was attired in a street length dress of teal blue crepe with which she wore White a White accessories. Her corsage was of pale pink cArnations.
 
Miss Betty Graham, sister of the groom, attended as maid of honor. She wore a shell pink dress with White accessories. Her corsage was also of pale pink carnations.
 
The groom wore a gray pinstriped suit and a pink carnation in his lapel. Mr. Bill Graham served his brother as best man. He wore a Brown suit with a pink cArnation in his lapel.
 
The bride attended The Woodsfield High School. Mr. Graham attended Graysville High School and served three years in The US Army.
 
The happy young couple are now making their home with the bride's parents. Their many friends extend congratulations and best wishes.

Green, Blanch Louella Arman X
          Mrs. Blanche Louella Arman, 85, of Powhatan, Route 1, died Thursday evening, February 9, 1967, at seven o clock in Bellaire City Hospital.  She was born at Steinersville, Ohio, January 19, 1882, a daughter of the late George W. And Zella Bonar Green.  Mrs. Arman was a member of the Amity Methodist Church.
          Surviving are her husband, Harry Arman; one daughter, Miss Helen Arman, of the home; one brother, Newell Green, of Powhatan, and one sister, Mrs. Gladys Gillespie, of Jacobsburg.  Two brothers, Waldo and Alfred Green, preceded her in death. Brief services were held Monday afternoon at one o clock in the Gibson-Bauknecht Funeral Home, at Powhatan.  Additional services were held at 1:30 o clock at the Amity Methodist Church, with Evangelist Leonard officiating.  Burial was in Powhatan Cemetery.

Green, Ethel, nee Rothaker
of Mrs. Ethel Green
January 12, 1933
Provided by Lena Kahrig Pettit, typed by Betty Lendon Matson
Mrs. Ethel Green, age 37 years, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Rothaker, of Round Bottom, died at her home at Jacobsburg, Belmont County, on Tuesday afternoon at 1:00 o'clock. She is survived by her husband, her parents and several brothers and sisters.
Funeral services will be held at the home of her parents on Friday afternoon at 1:00 o'clock followed by final obsequies at The Salem Evangelical Church. Interment will be made in the church cemetery.
 
Green, George W. Source--Wheeling News Register Wheeling, West Virginia Published---Saturday March 11, 1922
George W. Green, well known resident of Belmont County, passed away at his home on March 4 according to word received here yesterday. He was born in York Township, June 23, 1835, and at the time of his death was in his 87th year. He leaves the following children: Mary O. McManus, of Yorkville, Ohio; Robert B., William J., and John A. Interment was at Powhatan, Ohio.

January 26, 1931
 
Marriage
Newly Wed
Greenbank, Chester,-Zollinger Wedding
Published--1944
Mr. Chester Greenbank, T. M. 1/c, of the U.S. Navy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Geenbank of Lewisville, selected his home for his marriage to Miss Josephine Zollinger,
daughter of Mrs. Phoebe Zollinger of Sterling. The marriage took place Saturday afternoon, September 16th, at two o'clock, with Minister J.V.A. Traylor reading the impressive single room ceremony.
The bride was dressed in a blue suit with black accessories. She carried a bouquet of pink dahlias. As the bride's attendant, Miss Mildred Greenbank, sister of the groom, wore a pale blue dress with matching accessories. The best man was David Zollinger, brother of the bride.
A wedding dinner was served that evening at the home of the groom's parents with members of the immediate families present.
The groom is stationed at Bremerton, Washington, and has been in the service four years... The bride will make her home with her mother.
 
Greenbank, Dale Leon
Source--Newsclipping
Published--1955
Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Greenbank of Barberton, are the parents of a son, born March 15th in the Lodi Hospital. The new arrival weighed 9 pounds 11 ounces and has been named Dale Leon. Mrs. Greenbank is the former Miss Emily Bauman. The grandparents are Mr. and Mrs. A.R. Greenbank, of Sterling, Route 1, formerly of Lewisville, and Mrs. Maggie Bauman, also of Sterling. Dale Leon has one sister and seven brothers, including twin brothers.
Greenbank, Dorothy Blanche

Lewisville
 
Greenbank, Frank W.
Source--News Clipping
Published--1952
Greenbank, Frank W., 69, a lifelong resident of the Lewisville community, died Thursday evening, July 3rd. at 4:20 o'clock, after an extended illness.
He was engaged in the oil and gas business until his health failed him several weeks ago.
He is survived by four daughters; Mrs. Raymond (Mary E.) Weber, of Woodsfield; Mrs. Donald (Ruth) Schaffner, of North Canton; Miss Virginia Greenbank and Mrs. James (Joan) Paar of Canton; four grandchildren, John and Jane Ellen Weber of Woodsfield, and Richard and Susan Jane Schaffner of North Canton.
Funeral services were held at the Bauer and Turner Funeral Home on Sunday afternoon at three o'clock with the Reverend H.J. Kopke of the Evangelical and Reformed Church officiating. Interment was in Oaklawn Cemetery.
 
Greenbank, John
April 28, 1913
 
 
Greenbank, Martha Jane
July 17, 1918
Lewisville
 
 
GREENBANK, Mrs. Mary
Mrs. Mary KENNEDY Greenbank, widow of Richard GREENBANK, died at the home of her daughter, Mrs. George WEBER, of Oak Lawn Ave., Woodsfield Sunday, February 13, 1916, after a week s illness from pleuro-pneumonia, aged 76 years and 25 days. She was born near Summerfield, Monroe County, Ohio the daughter of William and Martha KENNEDY, and a well known and highly respected pioneer citizens of this County. On May 16, 1865, she was united in marriage with Richard GREENBANK, who preceded her to the better world in February 1900. To this union 8 children were born. Minnie and Irene GREENBANK died in infancy and Senoretta GREENBANK on February 29, 1904. Five children survive as follows: Jane, Delbert and Arthur GREENBANK, who reside on the old home farm east of Lewisville, Ohio; William K. GREENBANK, librarian at the Ohio Agricultural Experiment Station, Wooster, Ohio, and Mrs. George (Ida) WEBER, who resides on Oaklawn Avenue, Woodsfield, Ohio, and two brothers, John KENNEDY of Mt. Vernon, Ohio, and Arthur KENNEDY of Branch, Missouri, one sister, Mrs. Elizabeth FISHER, of near Lewisville, Ohio. The funeral was held Tuesday, February 15, after a beautiful and appropriate services conducted by the Reverend R. L. RYALL, pastor of the Presbyterian Church, officiating. Appropriate songs were sung by C. L. MELLOTT, W. T. RIST, Thomas MYERS and Samuel Christman of Woodsfield, after which the remains were laid beside her husband and other relatives in the Buchanan cemetery. Mrs. Mary GREENBANK was a faithful and consistent member of the Disciple s Church of Woodsfield for many years, and Long since had leArned to live the Christian life as well as profess it. The beautiful life just closed on earth.
Source:The Spirit of Democracy, Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, February 17, 1916
 
Greenbank, Oliver
November 3, 1927
 
 
Greenbank, Rosa
October 26, 1922
 
 
Greenbank, Thomas
May 15, 1917
Lewisville
 
 
Greenbank, W. K.
of W. K. Greenbank
Source:The Spirit of Democracy, dated, March 19, 1930
Provided by Lena Kahrig Pettit, typed by Betty Lendon Matson
W. K. Greenbank, former superintendent of Woodsfield schools, and for the past twenty years connected with The University of Wooster, died at his home in Wooster, Ohio, Monday evening. He had been ill from a complication of ailments for the past year.
Funeral services were held at Wooster, Ohio this Wednesday afternoon. Arthur Greenbank, of Lewisville, is a brother and Mrs. George Weber of Woodsfield, a sister of the deceased, and both attended the funeral services. Mr. Greenbank is also survived by his wife, who is the daughter of D. W. Smith, of Woodsfield; and by three sons and a daughter. They are; Lawrence, of Annapolis, Md.; Alfred, of Chicago; and Russell and Miss Eva of the home.
For several years, Mr. Greenbank was librarian at The University and later was made editor of the college publications which position he held at the time of his .
Many friends in Monroe County join in extending sympathy to the bereaved family.

Griffin, Miss Josephine and Mr. T. E. Drum
Source: The Spirit of Democracy
Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., December 21, 1916
Mr. T. E. DRUM a prominent business man of Woodsfield, and Miss Josephine GIFFEN of Bellaire, a former music teacher in the Woodsfield schools, were married at the home of the bride at Bellaire, Ohio Wednesday morning, December 20, 1916.
 

ENGAGEMENT

Griffin, Judy Annand and James Allen Thompson

Diana Sue Griffin of Lower Salem and Gary Griffin of Biloxi, MS are pleased to announce the engagement of their daughter Judy Ann Griffin, to James Allen Thompson, Jr., son of James Thompson, Sr. of Beallsville and Elaine Kinney of Woodsfield.

Judy is a 1992 graduate of Skyvue High School and Swiss Hills Vocational School. She is presently employed by Home Town Restaurant in Woodsfield.

Jim is a 1989 graduate of Woodsfield High School and Swiss Hills Vocational School. He is employed by Bridgeman's Honda in New Martinsville.

The wedding will be held May 14 at the Woodsfield Church of Christ at 4:30 p.m. with Keith Jones Officiating.

 
Griffin, Russell
July 2, 1891
February 1969
Graysville
 
Griffith, Alta
September 28, 1913
 
 
Griffith, Asher
Died: February 23, 1920
 
 
Griffith, Asher
 
 
October 6, 1916
Griffith, Asher
Killed by a Horse
The Spirit of Democracy
Thursday, October 12, 1916
Asher Griffith, a well known citizen of Greene Township, was killed by a horse at his home on Agin Ridge Friday forenoon. In just what manner he met his death will never be known as there were no witnesses to the tragedy. Mr. Griffith who was about sixty-eight years old, has made his home with his son John at the old home since the death of his wife three years ago. About half-past ten Friday morning the son said he would dig some potatoes, and the father went to the barn to lead a horse to water at the house. The horse was vicious, it is said, and the son saw the father start from the barn. In a very short time he noticed the horse running loose, and at once went to investigate, finding his father dead.
An inquest was held by H.J. Griffith, J.P. A bruise just over the heart and a broken rib were found. There was a small cut in the back of his head, which is supposed to have been caused by the fall on the ground.
The coroner's verdict was instantaneous death in accordance with the above stated facts.
Deceased leaves two sons, both of whom are married, Charles of Jerusalem and John, numerous relatives and friends to mourn his death. The funeral was held Sunday and was largely attended. Interment at Moffett's Cemetery.
 
Griffith, Cecil L.
October 25, 1929

Griffith, Elizabeth Griffith
 
 
March 19, 1915
 
 
Griffith, Ella J. Griffith
 
 
March 21, 1927
 
Marriage
GRIFFITH, Margaret and George BRITTAN
Published--The Spirit of Democracy Woodsfield, Ohio
February 7, 1918
 
On January 31, 1918, at St. Luke's Church, Wheeling Island, was solemnized the marriage of Mr. George Brittan of Bridgeport, Ohio, and Mrs. Margaret Griffith of North Braddock, Pa.
The bride is well known in Woodsfield and vicinity, being the daughter of the late H.B.
Hixenbaugh and wife, and is a lady amply qualified to make a home happy. The groom is unknown to the writer but is recommended as an industrious and well meaning gentleman.
Many friends here extend congratulations.
After the ceremony the happy couple went to Martins Ferry where a bountiful wedding supper had been prepared at the home of her brother Mr. William Hixenbaugh. After supper they went to their already furnished home near Bridgeport, Ohio and on Friday were elegantly entertained with a dinner given by her cousin Mrs. Lucas, at which time a large company was assembled to congratulate the happy couple and enjoy the good meal.

Griffith, Roswell J.
Death of Ross J. Griffith
Published January 7, 1932
Provided by Lena Kahrig Pettit, typed by Betty Lendon Matson
Ross J. Griffith, aged about 80 years, died at his home at Jerusalem Tuesday morning , January 5,1932, about 11o'clock.
Funeral services were held this Thursday afternoon at 1:30 o'clock at
The Jerusalem Presbyterian Church with Rev. W.H. Petry in charge. Interment was made at Ozark.

GRIMES, Miss Mattie
Friends here have received word of the of Miss Mattie GRIMES daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. J. GRIMES, of East Liverpool, who were former residents of this place, who died of ulceration of the stomach after an illness of eight weeks.

July 7, 1923
April 11, 2001
Hannibal
 
Groux, Samuel
Samuel Groux died at his home in Miltonsburg, June 12,1917. Deceased was born in Switzerland and came to this country when very young. Mr. Groux was well known throughout Monroe County, having served two terms as county commissioner. He was preceded to the beyond by his wife and one child, two children still survive. We have known Mr. Groux for many years and always found him an honest upright man. He was more than eighty years of age and lived a very active life.
Source: The Spirit of Democracy, Thursday, June 14, 1917
 
Groves, Delmas E.
May 12, 1915
November 2, 1987
Clarington
 
Groves, Eleanor
June 1st, 2004
 
Groves, Eleanor L., age 84 of Krebs Hill Road, Clarington died Tuesday, June 1, 2004 in Wetzel County Hospital, New Martinsville.
She was born June 5, 1919 in Powhatan Point, Ohio the daughter of the late Harry and Olive Isaly Nippert.
She was a 1937 graduate from Clarington High School, a former Secretary and Administrative Assistant with various offices, a member of Women s Guild and St. John s United Church of Christ, Powhatan Point, Ohio.
In addition to her parents, she was preceded in death by her husband, Delmer Groves, a brother, Boyd Nippert and a nephew, Dr. Ron Hathaway.
Survivors include two sisters, Elaine (H. William) Hathaway of Bowling Green, Kentucky and Fae (Charles) Robinson of Wooster, Ohio, a sister-in-law, Ann Nippert of Dayton, Ohio and several nieces and nephews.
A Memorial Service will be held on Sunday, July 18, 2004 at 1:30 p.m. at St. John s United Church of Christ, 51736 German Ridge Road, Powhatan Point, Ohio with Rev. Richard Wilson officiating. Inurnment in St. John s Church Cemetery, Powhatan Point.
Arrangements by Grisell Funeral Home, Clarington, Ohio.
Memorial contributions may be made to St. John s Church Cemetery Fund, c/o Ila Darrah, 52242 TH210, Powhatan Point, OH 43942.
 
Source--Grisell Funeral Home Obituaries -on-line
Published--June 1, 2004
Provided by Betty Lendon Matson

Source--Times Leader Martins Ferry, Ohio
Published--September 27, 2004
Groves, Ronald and Karen Elizabeth Riding
Mr. and Mrs. George Riding of Glen Dale, W.Va. announce the engagement of their daughter, Karen Elizabeth Riding to Ronald Lewis Groves II, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald L. Groves of St. Clairsville. The bride-to-be is a 1994 graduate of John Marshall High School and a 1998 graduate of BM Spurr School of Practical Nursing. Her fiance is a 1995 graduate of St. Clairsville High School. He attended Belmont Technical College and Ohio University Eastern. A fall wedding is planned.

Gust, Carl
Source--Times Leader Martins Ferry, Ohio
Published--October 9, 2004
Carl "Doorknob" Gust , 82, of Lansing, Ohio, formerly of Powhatan Point, Ohio, died Friday, October 8, 2004, in Wheeling Hospital Medical Park, Wheeling. He was born October 7, 1922, in Bellaire, the son of the late Ludwig and Mary Sayers Gust. He was a retired coal miner from Ohio Valley Coal and a Catholic by faith. In addition to his parents, he was preceded in death by an infant daughter, Christina Gust. Surviving are four sons, Larry (Zoe) Gust of Jacobsburg, Ohio, Richard (Linda) Gust of Bellaire, Gerry (Rita) Gust of Clarington, Ohio, and Michael (Veronica) Gust of Powhatan Point; a daughter, Pearl Kaldor of Powhatan Point; a stepson, John (Penny) Thompson of Vancouver, Washington; 16 grandchildren; 21 great-grandchildren; a special companion, Lucille Bennington of Powhatan Point; and special friends, Kevin Jackson, P.J. Asturi, Rebecca Bier and Billy Yocum. Services will be held at the convenience of the family. Arrangements are made by Grisell Funeral Home, Bellaire.In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Powhatan Emergency Squad, 104 Mellott Street, Powhatan Point, Ohio 43942.

Jimmy Hall
Death of Infant
Died: March 10, 1932
Provided by Lena Kahrig Pettit, typed by Betty Lendon Matson
Funeral services for Jimmy Hall, two day old son of Mr. and Mrs. Roe Hall, of East Marietta Street, were held Saturday. The services were in charge of the Rev. J. V. A. Traylor, pastor of The Woodsfield Church of Christ.
Besides the parents, several sisters and brothers survive. The bereaved family have the sympathy of the entire community. Burial was made in Pioneer Cemetery.

Hall, Walter Hall
 
 
December 19, 1930
Graysville
Hall, Walter
Died: December 19, 1930
Provided by Lena Kahrig Pettit, typed by Betty Lendon Matson
Walter, the fifteen-year old son of Charles Hall, of near Graysville, died at his home there Tuesday morning, death being due to a brain tumor. He had been ill only a few months and last summer was active in club work and attended club camp.
Besides his father, he is survived by his stepmother and one stepbrother, Stanley Hall, as well as many friends in his community.
Funeral services will be held on Thursday afternoon at 1:00 o'clock at Pleasant Ridge Church of Christ. The grief-stricken family have the sympathy of the entire community.

Hamilton, Carrie J. Hamilton
