Henthorn, Mahala J.
Mrs. Mahala Jane Henthorn, aged 78 years, relict of David Henthorn, died March 3, 1917, at her residence in Woodsfield. Deceased was a member of The Church of Christ and leaves one daughter; Mrs. Charles Adams of Bridgeport. The funeral was held Wednesday afternoon.
Source: The Spirit of Democracy, Thursday , March 8, 1917
 
Henthorn, Mary Piatt
Published--Thursday April 24, 2003
This young lady will be 90 years old on May 5. She was born to the late HoWard Piatt and Hilda (Heddleston) Piatt on May 5, 2003.
Mary remembers a lot of friends and relatives she grew up around. She now lives with her daughter and son-in-law, Betty and Lem Kindall of Massillon.
Mary has four grandchildren and 11 great grandchildren. She enjoys her grandchildren and before her failing health, she enjoyed quilting, sewing and gardening.
She was married to Lawrence Henthorn and enjoyed married life for over 60 years until his passing.
Family and friends are invited to send a note or card to wish her well. Her address is 825
Mathias St., N.E., Massillon, Ohio 44646.
She was 16 years old in one of the above photos and 88 in the other one. Isn't she cute?
There will be a family gathering and open house for family and close friends in celebration of her birthday.

Henthorn, Pittman, Mildred, nee Henthorn
Published--April 1999
Pittman, Mildred Irene, 79, 49780 Headly Ridge Road, Barnesville, died Sunday, April 4, 1999 in Wheeling Hospital. She was born, June 24, 1919, inAdams Township,Monroe County, a daughter of Everett and Susie Stewart Henthorn.
She was a member of The Zion Church of Christ, Beallsville.
In addition to her parents, she was preceded in death by her husband, Roy E. Pittman; a grandson, Roy J. "RJ" Ady; two brothers, Lawrence and Everett Henthorn.
Surviving are nine sons, Everett of Bowling Green, Ky., Roy Jr. of Oakland,Ky., Guy and Duane, both of Beallsville, James of Woodsfield, Roger and Bill, both of Sardis, Carl of Burbank, Ohio, Sam of Moundsville; five daughters, Hazel Blackstone of Wadsworth, Hilda Blackstone of Lewisville, Helen Palmer, Cordilia Knowlton and Barb Ady, all of Beallsville; two brothers, Charles Henthorn of Akron and Clarence Henthorn of Wadsworth; a sister Wanda Blackstone of Lewisville; 45 grandchildren; 35 great-grandchildren.
Services will be held today, April 7 at 1 p.m. at The Harper Funeral Home, 52728 Ohio
Avenue, Beallsville, with Wayne Clark officiating. Burial follows in East Sunbury Cemetery,Beallsville.

Henthorn, Virgil
March 24, 2004
Provided by Betty Lendon Matson
Virgil Henthorn, 75, of Beallsville, Ohio, died Wednesday, March 24, 2004 in Barnesville Hospital. He was born Feb. 19, 1929 near Beallsville, a son of the late Everett and Pearl Ward Henthorn.
He was a member of the Captina Church of Christ and a retired employee of the U.S. Postal Service.
In addition to his parents, Virgil was preceded in death by his wife, Nora "Bonnie" Henthorn.
Surviving are two daughters, Carol (Roger) Hornbaker of Delaware, Ohio and Sharon (Charles) Clark of Sparta, Ohio; four grandchildren, Nicole and Nathan Hornbaker and Amanda and Jacob Clark; a brother, Donald Henthorn of Rittman and a sister, Edna Mae (Ray) Truex of West Virginia.
Virgil will always be remembered for his concern for others. His door was always open with friendship and love.
Friends may call Friday from 5 to 8 p.m., at the Harper Funeral Home, Beallsville, where services will be held Saturday at 2 p.m. Burial follows in Beallsville Cemetery.

Hercher, Henry
May 8, 1895
Dec 1978
Sycamore Valley
 
Hercher, Lena Piatt

October 29, 1985

The Daily Jeffersonian, Cambridge, Ohio

 

Lena Piatt, nee Hercher

Woodsfield-Lena Piatt, 97, of Graysville R.D. 1, died at 11:20 a.m. Monday (Oct. 28, 1985) in Woodsfield Care Center following an extended illness.

She was born March 27, 1888, in Sycamore Valley, daughter of the late Albert and Theresa Swartz Hercher.

Mrs. Paitt attended the Lutheran Church.

Her husband, Frank Piatt, whom she married on Jan. 1, 1910, preceded her in death in July, 1945.

A son, Everett Piatt, four brothers, three sisters and grandson area also deceased.

She leaves two daughters, Mrs. Paul (Evelyn) Weddle of Graysville R.D. 1 and Mrs. Ona Tallman of Woodsfield; one son, Henry Piatt of Graysville R.D. 1; 13 grandchildren; 27 great-grandchildren and three great-great-grandchildren.

Friends may call 3 to 0 p.m. Wednesday and 9 a.m. until time of the 2 p.m. services Thursday at Watters Funeral Home in Woodsfield. The Rev. Robert Piatt and the Rev. Stephen Sparling will officiate. Burial will be in Oaklawn Cemetery in Woodsfield.

Hetti, Carolyn Nuzum

Death

December 18, 1987

The Spirit of Democracy, Woodsfield, Ohio

 

Carolyn Nuzum, 87, nee Hetti

Carolyn Dorothy Nuzum, 87, of Holiday Avenue, Woodsfield, died at 11:30 p.m. Tuesday, December 15, 1987 at Route 3, Woodsfield, following an extended illness. She was born in Monroe County on December 15, 1900 a daughter of the late Henry and Eva Matz Hetti.

She was a graduate of the Bethesda School of Nursing, Cincinnati, and had worked for many years at Barnesville Hospital as a registered nurse. She was also a member of the St. Paul s United Church of Christ, Woodsfield.

On November 7, 1974, she married Palmer Nuzum who survives of Woodsfield. Also surviving are five step-daughters, Mrs. Thelma Shaw of Lumberport, W. Va., Mrs. Betty Hunt, Warren, Mrs. Ellen Porch, Alliance, Mrs. Minerva Worthem, California and Mrs. Goldia Douglas, Ravenna; five step-sons also survive, Eugene and Harold Nuzum both of Alliance, Howard Nuzum, Grand Rapids, Michigan, Herman Nuzum, Clarksburg, W. Va.; several step-grandchildren; nieces and nephews.

She was preceded in death by one step-son and one step-daughter.

Friends were received at the Watters Funeral Home, Woodsfield Thursday where funeral services were held Friday with Rev. Richard M. Wright of the St. Paul s United Church of Christ officiating. Burial followed in the Friendship Cemetery, Lewisville.

 
Hettig, Edith, nee Morris

Woodsfield-Edith Awaiva Morris Hettig, 75, Lewisville R.D. 2, died Saturday morning (June 8, 1985) at her home.

She was born July 10, 1909, in Monroe County, a daughter of the late Henry and Eva Smith Morris.

Mrs. Hettig was a member of the Bracken Ridge United Methodist Church near Lewisville.

Her husband, Marf H. Hettig, died March 5, 1978.

She leaves one son, Paul Hettig of the home; four daughters, Mrs. Everett (Carolyn) Pittman of Bowling Green, Ky., Mary Hettig of the home, Mrs. George (Linda) Larrick of Cumberland and Mrs. Michael (Donna) Packard of Burbank; nine grandchildren and two great-grandchildren.

Friends may call 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. today at Watters Funeral Home, Woodsfield where services will be 1 p.m. Tuesday with the Rev. John Powell officiating. Burial will be in Bracken Ridge Church Cemetery near Lewisville.

source: Monroe county beacon, June 10, 1985

Hicks, Mrs. Christina, nee Kiedaisch
SOURCE: Times-Leader, Dec 17, 1963, pg 2
Mrs. Christina Hicks, 82, widow of Hugh Hicks, and resident of Hannibal, died Monday morning at the Wetzel County Hospital, New martinsville. She was born July 24, 1881, at Hannibal and was a member of the Mt. Zion United Church of Christ.
Surviving are a son, David of Wheeling; one daughter, Mrs. Virgil Huffman, with whom she resided; a brother, Raymond Kiedaisch of Hannibal, two sisters, Miss Ricca Kiedaish of Washington, D.C., and Miss Nellie Kiedaisch of Beallsville; two grandchildren and a great-grandchild.
Friends are being received at the Rush Funeral Home, Sardis, where services will be conducted Wednesday at 2 p.m. by Rev. George Corbitt. Burial in Greenlawn Memorial Park, New Martinsville.
 
Hicks, Gloria Eileen Mary, nee Pritchard
Died: February 16, 1968
Provided by Lena Kahrig Pettit, typed by Betty Lendon Matson
Hicks, Gloria Eileen Mary, 44, formerly of Hannibal,O., died February 16, 1968 in Taipei, Taiwan where she had lived for the past 15 years. She was born on June 14, 1912 in Shanghai, China, daughter of William and Lilly Pritchard. Survivors include her husband, Hugh H. Hicks; three daughters, Janet L. and Susan L. and one son, Hugh P., all of the home; her parents,one sister, Mrs. Mildred Gramm, Melbourne, Australia.
Friends may call at The Rush Funeral Home, Clarington, O. after 1 p.m. where services will be held Saturday at 2 p.m.; in charge of Rev. Paul Brown with interment in Greenlawn Memorial Cemetery, New Martinsville.

Highman, Alma L.
 
June 23, 1899
 
February 1989
 
Woodsfield
 
Highman, Audrey, Gatten, Shafer (1st spouse: Oliver Thurman Gatten)
Source: The Monroe County Beacon, Woodsfield, Ohio, May 1999
Audrey Luzelle Highman Gatten Shafer, 90, of Woodsfield Nursing and Rehabilitation Center, Woodsfield, formerly of Route 2, Lewisville, died May 16, 1999 at Barnesville Hospital. She was born March 14, 1909 at Sarahsville, Ohio, a daughter of the late Charles Highman and Pearl Nalley Highman.
She was a member of the Richfork Church of Christ. She lived her life based on the concept of the Golden Rule. Her family can attest to her love, patience and self-sacrifice. She will be remembered by her friends and neighbors for her hospitality, friendliness and generosity.
Surviving are her second husband, John L. Shafer, of Woodsfield, whom she married April 20, 1974; two sons, Kenneth Gatten, Enfield, Connecticut, and Delmas Gatten, of Woodsfield, three daughters, Eula kahrig of Pataskla, Sue Kuhn of Lancaster and Amy Highman of Ashland; three stepdaughters, Doris McFadden, Helen Rosenbluh, and Dorothy Smith, all of ashland; a stepson, John Shafer, Jr. of ashland; 21 grndchildren; and 22 great-grandchildren; and four great-great grandchildren.
Friends were received from 6 to 9 p.m. Tuesday at Bauer-Turner Funeral Home, Woodsfield, where services were held at 11 a.m. Wednesday with Minister Donald Highman and Lester Kahrig officiating. Burial was in Oaklawn Cemetery, Woodsfield, Ohio.
 
Highman, David [Source:The Spirit of Democracy Woodsfield, Ohio, Thurs., July 25, 1889 and another printing was made on August 15, 1889]
On last Friday, July 19, 1889, Mr. David Highman, one of the oldest residents of Wayne Township died at his home on Rich Fork creek. He had reached the advanced age of 89 years. Interment in Conner Ridge cemetery on last Sabbath.
August 15, 1889, issue: On July 19, 1889, David Highman, one of the oldest residents of Wayne township died at the residence of his son, Marcus Highman, on Richfork Creek in Wayne township, this County, aged 89 years, two months, and six days. Deceased had eleven children, fifty-seven grandchildren and ninety-six great grandchildren. He was married to Jane Lowe in 1824, near Bellaire, Ohio. He lived in Ohio until his first child was born, then moved to Pennsylvania where three more children were born, then moved to Virginia when three more were born, then moved to Ohio some fifty years ago and four more children were added to them. He entered eighty acres of land under Van Buren which he held until about five years ago when he sold out to his son with whom he lives. On the 28th February 1877, he was stricken with paralysis of the right side which caused him to lay in bed for over twelve Long years, but during all this period of time, there never was a murmur or complaint escaped his lips. He did not seen to suffer much until about four weeks before he died, but then he suffered untold agonies and even then in his patience he reminded one of Job, such patience and seeming cheerfulness the writer never witnessed. He had all the care that loving hands and sympathizing friends could administer to him. He died without an enemy and was always a good neighbor, friendly with everybody. To know him was to love him. He was followed to the Connor cemetery by a large concourse of people, the Long, which showed the esteem in which he was held, and was laid to rest besides his wife who preceded him some nine years ago. Six children are left to mourn the loss of a king and an affectionate father and the community loses one of its best citizens. His life and character was one worthy of imitation. L. W. W.
 
Highman, David E.
Source--Monroe County Beacon Woodsfield, Ohio
Published--Thursday May 1, 1997
David Ellsworth Highman, 92, of 317 Guiford Avenue, Woodsfield, died April 25, 1997 at the Woodsfield Nursing and Rehabilitation Center. He was born in Wayne Township, Monroe County, July 22, 1904, a son of Abner and Phoebe Drake Highman.
He was a retired farmer, school teacher and oil producer. He was a member of Rich Fork Church of Christ, a member of the Monroe County Education Association and a lifetime member of the State Teacher's Association.
Surviving are his wife, Gladys Bates Highman, of Woodsfield,; two sons, Hubert Highman of Canton and David Highman of Columbus; three daughters, Eva Jean Hartshorn, of Graysville, Martha Graham Zerger, of Woodsfield and Barbara Sherry , Woodsfield, 17 grandchildren, 17 great grandchildren and two great-great-grandchildren
In addition to his parents, he was preceded in death by two daughters, Phyllis and Lorna Highman; one infant son, Byron Highman; three brothers, Jay, Otto and Alonzo Highman; two sisters, Georgia Williams, Arena Cline; one grandson, Reginald Duane Hartshorn.
Friends were received April 28 at the Bauer-Turner Funeral Home, Woodsfield, where services were held April 29, with Minister Herbert Alexander officiating. Interment in the Oaklawn Cemetery, Woodsfield, Ohio.
 
Highman, Denzel C.
Source--Columbus Dispatch Columbus, Ohio
Published--Sunday, April 4, 1999
Funeral services for Denzel C. Highman, age 88, of Columbus will be 11 a.m. Tuesday, April 6,1999 at Emerson-Newkirk-Warhime Funeral Home, Kirkersville with Reverend Carol Weiss officiating. Burial will follow in Pataskala Cemetery.
Mr. Highman died Saturday morning, April 3,1999 at his home. Born May 12, 1910 in Woodsfield, Ohio, he was the son of the late Delbert and Alta(Green) Highman.
Mr. Highman retired in 1975 from the Arkansas Best Motor Freight Company where he worked as a truck driver.
He was a member of the Martinsburg United Methodist Church.
Survived by his wife, Evelyn (Janes) Highman, Columbus; sons and daughters-in-law, Robert and Nancy Highman of Parma, Ohio, Richard and Holly Highman of Sunbury, Ohio, grandchildren, Scott Highman of Parma, Ohio, Heather Highman, Spruce Pine, North Carolina and Judy Highman, Sunbury, Ohio; many nieces and nephews also survive.
Preceded in death by 3 sisters.
Friends may call from 7-9 p.m. Monday at the funeral home, 285 East Main Street, Kirkersville. The family suggests contributions to the American Heart Association, 5455 North High Street, Columbus, Ohio 43214
 
HIGHMAN, Duncan
   Duncan Highman was born January 18, 1837, and died May 28, 1907 aged 70 years and four months.  He was united in marriage to Sarah M. Byers, daughter of Abner Byers, April 27, 1865.  To this union was born nine children, eight sons and one daughter, all of whom survived him except two sons.  His wife and children were at his bedside and watched the departing and with sorrow not without hope wept over broken ties so near to them. 
   He was a member of the Connor M.E. Church at the time of his and during his last days of suffering entered into a deeper religious experience and spoke joyfully of his hope in heaven. 
   He served his country faithfully for three years in the war of the rebellion.  He was a member of Co. B., 25th Regiment Ohio Volunteer Infantry.  He was wounded July 1, 1863, at the battle of Gettysburg, Pa., and was mustered out July 16, 1864 on expiration of term of service.  The deceased has been a lifeLong citizen of Monroe County and will be greatly missed by his many friends.  The funeral services were conducted at his home by Joseph L. Oden assisted by Jacob Willison, after which his remains were taken to the Connor Ridge cemetery where it was laid to rest, there "to await the resurrection of the just."
 
Highman, Miss Edna Arrena and Mr. Alonzo E. Cline
Source:The Spirit of Democracy, Thursday, January 16,1913
    On Saturday morning, January 11, 1913, Mr. Alonzo E. Cline and Miss Edna Arrena Highman accompanied by their brothers Alonzo Highman and Charles Cline, drove over to Woodsfield and secured a marriage permit and were married by "Squire Hoeffler."  After the ceremony was performed they returned to the home of the brides parents, Mr. and Mrs. Abner Highman and where they found about fifty invited guests had assembled for the occasion. After extending congratulations and best wishes and spending a short time in social conversation, we were invited to the dining room where we found a table loaded with all the good things the season afforded to which all did ample justice. The bride, who is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abner Highman, was dressed in white silk which was very appropriate for the occasion. The groom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Christian Cline and wore a suit of Brown serge. Mr. and Mrs. Cline are highly respected young people, he being one of Monroe Counties leading school teachers and no doubt did well in choosing her for his life companion. The afternoon was spent in music and conversation then followed the distribution of the presents as follows: Abner Highman $100, Mrs. Abner Highman, set of dishes; Georgia Highman, rocker; Mr.and Mrs. Alta Highman, pitcher and spoon holder; Austin Sloan, dish; Mary Sloan, dish; Della Sloan, dish; Mr. and Mrs. O. E. Highman, tablecloth; Mr and Mrs. A. H. Highman $1; S. M. Highman, bedspread; Guy Edington 50 cents; Charles Cline $1; Clarence Highman, two dishes; D. E. Hartshorn and family , bedspread; James Drake, cake set; Lillian D. Lucas, dish; Olive Cronin, dish; Eska Steed, dish; Mr. and Mrs. D. O. Jones, two dishes & Alonzo Highman, dish. In the evening we returned to our homes feeling that the day was well spent and hoping to be present on many such occasions.
                                                                            One who was there

Mrs. Highman was a graduate of Kirkersville High School.
Surviving are:
Sons & Daughters-in-law:

Richard & Holly Highman - Sunbury

She was preceded in death by her husband, Denzil C. Highman, on April 3, 1999; and by a brother, Ernest Janes; and a sister, Merle Regan.
Friends may call from 7-9 PM on Friday, May 10, at the funeral home, 285 East Main Street, Kirkersville.
Memorial contributions may be made to the Condit Presbyterian Church, 15102 Hartford Road, Sunbury, OH 43074.

Highman, Jacob Parry (twin)
Source:The Spirit of Democracy, dated, Thursday, August 21, 1902
Last Friday, August 15, 1902, Jacob Parry Highman, John Gatten and Harry Highman of Edwina were squirrel hunting. In some accidental manner Gatten discharged his gun, the Ball entering Jacob Highman's stomach, passed through his body and out at the small of his back. The Ball struck Harry Highman's hat, but did not injure him. Highman was taken home and Dr. A.F. Latta of
Graysville and Dr. F.C. Huth of Woodsfield were summoned but the wound was of such nature as to defy all medical skill and the unfortunate young man died Friday night.
 
Deceased was a son of Mr. and Mrs. Duncan (Emily) Highman and was fifteen years of age. He leaves father, mother and other relatives and friends to mourn his departure. The funeral took place Saturday. Interment at the Conner church cemetery.
 
Marriage (becky: I haven t figured out the parents of this Hamilton Highman)
Hamilton Highman - Alma Menkel Bigler marriage
Source:The Monroe County Beacon, Woodsfield, OH. , dated, Thursday, July 31, 1941
Announcement has been made of the marriage of Mrs. Alma Bigler, of Woodsfield and Hamilton Highman, of the Woodsfield, Graysville road. The ceremony was performed Saturday night at 11:30 o'clock at the home of the bride in the presence of Everett Highman, son of the bridegroom; Lawrence Bigler, a son of the bride; Mrs J. V. A. Traylor and daughter Barbara, of Woodsfield. Minister J. V. A. Traylor officiated at the exchange of vows.
The bride was attired in a beige crepe dress with which she wore Brown accessories.
The bride is employed as a clerk in the M. & K. Store in Woodsfield, while her husband is employed with the State Highway Department in Monroe County.
The couple will make their home at the home of the bride until September 1, which they will move to Mr. Highman's home on the Woodsfield- Graysville road.
Personal note: (Alma Menkel
Alma was born in 1899, quite high school when she was 16, went to
Akron to live with Edna when she and Paul were married and worked at
the Goodrich and Goodyear Rubber shops. Married Lawrence Bigler in
1920, and had four children by the time he died in 1932 and she went
back to Woodsfield. Worked ten years, and then married Hamilton
Highman in 1941 and had one son Ray in 1943. Became a widow again in
1962.)
 
(Maggie June Hoover is spouse of Frank Hoover)
Glenn Leroy is son of Charles Franklin Highman and Pearl Josephiine Nalley Highman.
 
MARRIGE, 1940
Highman-Hoover marriage
Mrs. Maggie June Hoover, of Woodsfield, Ohio, announces the marriage of her daughter, Miss Edna Hoover to Mr. Glenn Leroy Highman, of near Graysville, which was solemnized at Covington, Kentucky, October 19, 1940. The bride was attired in a street length dress of blue crepe with corresponding accessories of blue, while the bridegroom was also dressed in a suit of navy blue. They are making their home in Middletown, Ohio, where the groom has employment. Friends are extending congratulations and best wishes to the happy couple
Source:The Monroe County Beacon, dated, November 28, 1940

Highman: Lawrence Eugene
Graysville, Ohio - Lawrence E. Highman, 87, of 39016 State Route 26, Graysville, died at 4:18 p.m. Saturday (July 24, 2004) upon arrival at Marietta Memorial Hospital in Marietta.
He was born near Woodsfield, Ohio, on November 27, 1916, a son of the late Otto and Mary Jones Highman.
He was a retired maintenance worker for Ormet Corp. in Hannibal and was a farmer. He was a member of Graysville United Methodist Church in Graysville. He was a U.S. Army veteran of World War II and was a member of Disabled American Veterans.
In addition to his parents, he was preceded in by two brothers, Glenn and Ronald Highman; and one sister, Mabel Watts.
Surviving are his wife, Gladys Smith Highman, whom he married on June 22, 1946; five sons, Daryl Highman and his wife, Nina, of Senecaville, Paul Highman and his wife, Becky, of Woodsfield, Greg Highman and his wife, Susan, of Graysville, Roger Highman and his wife, Jackie, of Woodsfield, and Roy Highman and his wife, Melody, of Graysville; one brother, Virgil Highman of Newark; three sisters, Neva Klemanns of Guilford Lake, Ohio, Carolyn Love of Woodsfield and Bonnie Bertschy of Creston, Ohio; nine grandchildren; two great-grandchildren; and several nieces and nephews.
Friends will be received from 2 to 9 p.m. Tuesday at Watters Funeral Home, 37501 State Route 78 West, Woodsfield, where funeral services will be held at 1 p.m. Wednesday with the Rev. Gary Fitzgerald, the Rev. Tom Scott and the Rev. Madelynn Webber officiating. Burial will follow in Low Gap Cemetery near Graysville with full military graveside services.
Memorial contributions may be made to the American Heart Association, 4916 Hills and Dales Road, N.W., Canton, Ohio 44708; or to the American Cancer Society, 215 Marion St., Marietta, Ohio 45750.
Source--Marietta Times Marietta, Ohio
Published--July 26, 2004
 
Highman, Lowell Gray
Source--The Journal Leader Caldwell, Ohio
Published--Monday May 18, 1998
Highman, Lowell Gray, passed away November 15, 1998 at Riverside Methodist Hospital, Columbus, Ohio.
Born December 15, 1926 in Sarahsville, Ohio, he was the only son of the late Sylvester and Elizabeth J. Truex Highman.
He was a graduate of Sarahsville High School, attended Ohio State University, was a T4 army veteran of World War II serving with the Asiatic Pacific Theatre, and was a proprietor of Highman General Store in Sarahsville before moving to Columbus where he was affiliated with Constructions Systems, Incorporated.
His wishes were to donate his remains for the advancement of medical science. This invaluable contribution was recently completed at the Ohio State University Medical Center, Columbus, Ohio.
Survivors include cousins; Jeanne Truex, William Truex, Dessie Truex Powell, Viola Truex Varner, Leland Truex, Ray Truex, Glen Truex and many friends.
Memorial service will be Saturday, May 23 at 1:00 p.m. at Sarahsville Methodist Church with Pastor Wendy Erb officiating. Interment will follow in Village View Cemetery with Caldwell Veterans of Foreign Wars Post 4721 conducting military services.
Memorials may be made to Sarahsville Methodist Church.
 
HIGHMAN,  MARCUS  son of David Highman and Jane Lowe Highman, spouse: Mary (polly) Snider) 
Marcus Highman, who departed this life November 11, 1906, was at the time of his , 75 years of age. He leaves a wife and eight children, one brother and one sister. Three children, three brothers and five sisters preceded him to the grave. His children living are Malisse Smith, of Washington County, Mollie Hamilton, of near Pittsburg, Ella Dougherty of Toronto, Jefferson County, Ohio. Jane FArnsworth of Edwina, Monroe County; James and Sylvester Highman, of near Edwina, Duncan Highman of near Sarahsville, Noble County, and Charles of
Bellaire, Belmont County. His brother Duncan Highman and sister Hannah J. Gatten of near Edwina, Monroe County. He leaves several grandchildren and great grandchildren besides a host of friends whose hearts were made sad to hear of his sudden .
  Mr. Highman has lived nearly all his life in this neighborhood near Edwina until a few days before his and he and his wife moved to their son Duncan's farm near Sarahsville, Noble County. Deceased had a stroke of paralysis Friday, November 9, and he died on Sunday, November 11. The remains were brought back and buried in the Conner Cemetery on Tuesday, November 13, just two weeks after he moved to his new home in Noble County. Funeral services were conducted by Jacob Willison.
  Mr. Highman was baptized and joined the M. E. Church at Conner  several years ago of which he was a member at the time of his . He possessed many good and noble traits of character which endeared him to his family and neighbors and all with whom he associated. He was strictly honest in all his Dealing, a truthful, upright, good citizen, one that will be greatly missed by all who knew him.
  "Be ye also ready for ye know not the day nor the hour wherein the son of man cometh." A  FRIEND
Source:The Spirit of Democracy, dated, Thursday, November 29, 1906

Hill, Alice I.
Dec 16, 1907
October 1988, residence: Woodsfield
Source: Monroe County records
 
Hill, Allen Eugene
" Rambler at Rest"
The Spirit of Democracy"
Thursday , January 6, 1916
Allen Eugene Hill passed to his reward, December 27, 1915, at his home at Washington, D.C. He "knew in whom he believed," and was of a modest and retiring disposition, and of a noble upright character and for those, we know "eye hath not seen, nor ear heard, neither have entered into the heart of man, the things which God hath prepared for them that love him." He was better known to the people of Monroe County as "Rambler ", the name he gave himself while writing for our papers.. The letters he wrote in his extensive travels through Europe were interesting and instructive and were eagerly watched for and carefully read by both friends and strangers. That he well earned the title "Rambler" we will endeavor to give in a short history.
Allen E. Hill was born in Woodsfield, December 12,1848, and was the son of Hugh B. and Mary Driggs Hill. He remained in Woodsfield until the time of The Civil War, when but a lad went as a volunteer in the 4th Va. Calvary. At the close of the war he returned to Woodsfield and remained a few months when, he went to St. Louis, Mo., on March 5,1866. September 4, 1866 he enlisted in The Regular Army and remained the five years, returning home in 1871. In 1872 he went to Iowa thinking he would like farm life and settle down. Went from Iowa to Albine, Kansas on Feb.16, 1874. He returned to Woodsfield in 1875 and took up the study of law in the office of Spriggs and Driggs and after completing the coarse he practiced here for a short time. He went to the inauguration of James A. Garfield and while visiting relatives the roving spirit again took possession of him and he joined The Marine Service and during the five years on the sea saw all of Europe. In 1886 he went to Washington D.C., and engaged in the real estate business with an uncle, Elias Hill. In October 1890, he was married to Miss Nannie English of Washington D. C., to which union was born ,Irene, at home, Wilmer, who is now in Cuba holding a responsible position, and Geraldine and Audrey, who died in infancy.
For a number of years he occupied an important position with the Washington Loan and Trust Company and was respected by all in the office. He held this position until the beginning of his illness four years ago of hardening of the arteries . During all that time, he was a great sufferer, yet patient , through it all and during the time kept himself informed on current events both religious and state.
He was buried with Masonic rites on Thursday at three o'clock, he being a member of Lafayette Chapter Royal Arch Masons, also a member of The Order of Eastern Stars and of The Lincoln Post G.A.R.
He was a member of The Brookland M. E. Church. A former pastor, E.C. Powers, assisted by J.P. Wright conducted the services at the church. The flowers were beautiful especially the emblems from the various orders.
Besides his widow and children there remains to mourn, one brother, H.B. Hill of Bellaire and five sisters; Mrs. James Rouse and Mrs. Ella Beardmore of Woodsfield , Mrs.. Anthony Dorr of Batesville , Mrs. John Reed of St. Louis and Mrs. Hattie McCormick of Sistersville, W. Va.
O friends of mortal years
The trusted and the true,
You are watching still in the valley of tears,
But I wait to welcome you.
Do I forget? O No!
For memories golden chain,
Shall bind my heart to the hearts below
"Till we meet to touch again.
 
Hill, Charles
February 19. 1913
Source: Monroe County records
Hill, Erma L.
Source-Jackson County Message Board West Virginia
Published 2000
Hill, Erma L. , age 81, of Letart Falls, Ohio, died September 19, 2000, at the home
of her daughter on Lighthouse Road in Letart Falls, Ohio.
She was a housewife and a member of the East Letart United Methodidt Church.
She is survived by her daughter, Linda Turley, Letart Falls, Ohio; grandchildren,
Kirk Turley and Hillary Turley, both of Letart Falls, Ohio; sisters, Virginia Salser, Syracuse,
Ohio, and Lois Jean Mugrage, Woodsfield, Ohio; brother and sister-in-law; Dallas and Donna
Hill, Apple Grove, Ohio; brothers-in-law; Willard Wagner, Stockport, Ohio, and Harold Roush,
Racine, Ohio; sisters-in-law; Inez Hill, Pauline Hill, Katie Hill, all of Racine, Ohio; Helen Bailey,
Syracuse, Ohio, Ora Hill; numerous nieces and nephews.
She was preceded in death by her husband, John N. Hill, April 30, 1999, father and mother; brothers
Harold, Samuel and Tom Barnhart; sisters, Wilma Brooks, Eula Wagner and Betty Urban.
Services will be held on Thursday, September 21, 2000, at 1:00 p.m. at Roush Funeral Home,
Ravenswood, West Virginia with Reverend Brian Harkness officiating. Burial will follow in
Letart Falls Cemetery, Racine, Ohio. Friends may call at Roush Funeral Home on Wednesday,
September 20, 2000, from 2:00 to 4:00 and 7:00 to 9:00 p.m.

HIll, Ford E.

Ford E. Hill, 69

Ford E. Hill, 69, of New Matamoras, OH, Route 1, died Saturday Jan. 31, 1987, at the home of his niece Mrs. Karen Edinger of Brownsville, after a long illness.

He was born Feb. 4, 1917, in Monroe Co. the son of the late Worthy G. and Alice Cline Hill.

He was a retired farmer and a veteran of World War II.

He is survived by (2) sisters: Mrs. Kathleen Barnhart of Lowell, OH, Mrs. Grethel Ring of Lewisville, OH.

Friends were received Sunday from 3-9 p.m. and Monday from 3:30 -9 p.m. at the Bauer-Turner Funeral Home in Woodsfield where services were held Tuesday at 1 p.m. with Rev. Stephen Sparling officiating.

Burial was held in Ring Mills.

Hill, Leo
Source:The Marietta Times, dated Tuesday, March 16, 2004
Provided by Betty Lendon Matson
Leo R. Hill, 67, of Main Street, Jerusalem, Ohio died Sunday at home.
He was born June 21, 1936 in Grand Coulee, Wash., a son of the late Charles Lewis Hill and Mabel Secrest Hill.
He was a retired mill wright form Conalco Corporation, Hannibal, Ohio, and a U.S. Army veteran.
Preceded in death by his former wife, Mary C. Hill, and his former mother-in-law Francis Steed Gray.
Surviving are two sons, Lewis Hill, Woodsfield, Ohio, Richard Hill, Woodsfield, Ohio; three daughters, Donna Darby, Jerusalem, Ohio, Vonna Pittman and her husband Leonard,Beallsville, Ohio, Ohio, Kay Cooper and her husband Douglas, Middlebourne, W.Va.; one brother Wayne Hill, Miami, Okla; one sister Donna Tiller, Tocoma, Wash; 10 grandchildren; one step grandchild; two great grandchildren; several nieces and nephews.
Friends received from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. Friday, March 19, 2004 at the Bauer-Turner Funeral Home, 100 S. Paul St., Woodsfield, Ohio. Interment at the convenience of the family.

Hill, Roxie
Died: November 20, 1915. Source: Monroe County death records
Hill, Simon
Died: June 26, 1919. Source: Monroe County death records
Hill, Tammy Ann and Kenneth Allan Shafer

Tammy Ann Hill became the bride of Kenneth Allan Shafer on October 8, 1988 at Paw-Paw United Methodist Church, Germantown. The bride is the daughter of Dennis and Janet Hill of Lower Salem and the bridegroom is the son of Kenneth and Dorothy Shafer of Sarahsville.

Reverend Bob Schafer officiated the 4:00 p.m. candlelight and double ring ceremony. Music was provided by Dale Morris and Tammy Rinehart, cousin of the groom. Selections included "Nobody Loves Me Like You Do," "Heaven," "There Is Love" and "Forever and Ever, Amen."

The mothers of the couple lit the family altar candles and from these the bride and bridegroom lit their unity candle during the ceremony. The altar was adorned with candelabras and urns of white daisies carnations, gladioli, and baby's breath mixed with a variety of greenery. The flower arrangements were in honor of the couple's late grandparents. Edison Shafer, Albert Hill, and William and Anna Leasure.

Gives in marriage by her parents and escorted by her father, the bride wore a sparkling white crystal organza gown. The gown featured a pearl trim wedding band collar onto an illusion yoke and jeweled sweetheart bodice. The poet sleeves were adorned with cut out lace insets and swirls of schiffli embroidery fell across the tops of her hands. Large beaded medallions graced the full skirt sweeping to a chapel train of frothy organza ruffles and lace. The bride's veil was a three-tier walking length nylon with blusher trimmed with simulated pearls. She carried a cascading bouquet of white stephanotis, sweetheart roses, tinted baby carnations, iridescent pearls and bells, and baby's breath. The bouquet was trimmed with a variety of ivy and satin streamers. The bride's jewelry consisted of a pair of cultured pearl earrings given to her as a wedding gift from the bridegroom.

Teresa Johnson cousin of the bride, served as matron of honor. She wore a glowing satin daphne rose gown, lavished with lace. Her hair flower spray and heels were in the contrasting color of her gown. She carried a bouquet of daphne rose tinted sweetheart roses, baby carnations, baby's breath and streamers.

Bridesmaids were Barbara Holiday and Darla Griffin, friends of the bride. The bridesmaids were dressed identical in the matron of honor except in colors of teal and royal blue. All wore pearl necklaces given them by the bride.

Kevin Johnson. friend of the bridegroom, served as his best man. Dan Shafer, uncle of the bridegroom, and Bill Close, cousin of the bride, served as ushers.

Lori Chambers, cousin of the bride, served as flower girl. She was dressed identical to the matron of honor. Tom Rea, cousin of the bride served as ring bearer. Joyce Rea, aunt of the bride and Angie Kahrig, cousin of the bride, presided at the guest book. Tammy Long cousin of the bride, presided at the guest book. Tammy Long, cousin of the bridegroom distributed thank you scrolls.

A reception of the 150 guests followed at the Dalzell Town Hall. Serving as aides were: Ruth Bates, Rosie Rea, Lois Grubb, Patricia Neill, and Nancy Cozby. The reception was followed by a dance with Blue Denim providing the music.

The new Mrs. Shafer is a 1987 graduate of Fort Frye High School and is presently self employed.

The bridegroom is a 1985 graduate of Shenandoah High School and is presently employed at Dexter Hardwoods, Dexter City. The couple is residing at Lower Salem.

 

 
Hill, Wanda V.
Born: Aug 8, 1912, died: Mar 4, 2002, residence: Woodsfield
Source: Monroe County records
 
Hill, William Bailey
Death of Bailey Hill
Source:The Spirit of Democracy, dated, December 30, 1930
Provided by Lena Kahrig Pettit, typed by Betty Lendon Matson
Rites for William Bailey Hill,77, whose death occurred at four o'clock Monday morning at his home, 4274 Harrison Street, Bellaire, were conducted Tuesday evening at eight o'clock at the Grafton- Bauknecht-Mellott mortuary on Thirty-seventh St., Bellaire. Rev. J. W. Douds, pastor of The M.E. Church,officiated. Wednesday morning the body was removed to Woodsfield and taken to the home of Mrs. Ella Beardmore, where final rites were held at one o'clock. Interment in the Oaklawn Cemetery at Woodsfield.
Deceased was born in Monroe County but had resided in Bellaire for the past 40 years. He was affiliated with The First M.E. Church.
Bereaved by his death are his widow, Mrs. Mary J. Hill, and one son, Hugh Hill of Warwood, and one daughter, Mrs. William Nesbit. Four sisters and five grandchildren also survive.
Mr. Hill was a brother of Mrs. Ella Beardmore and the late Mrs. James G. Rouse, also of Mrs. Hattie McCormick, of Sistersville, W.Va.; Mrs. Tirzah Reid, of Rockford, Illinois, and Mrs. Lenora Dorr of Columbus.
Mr. Hill had visited in Woodsfield frequently and was honored and respected by all who knew him.

Source: Monroe County records
 
Hinderlong, Alma Louise Marie (Schrader)
Source--News Clipping
Published--1954
Hinderlong, Mrs. Alma Louise Marie Schrader, the daughter of George and Christine Smith Schrader, was born on March 2, 1888, and departed this life July 1, 1954, at the age of 66 years and four months.
She was baptized on April 8, 1888 and confirmed on April 5, 1903 in Saint Peter's Evangelical Church of Miltonsburg by Pastor Albrecht.
On April 22, 1909 she was united in marriage with Charles H. Hinderlong. To this union were born one daughter, Maida. Her husband preceded her in death on October 12, 1941.
She is the last of a family of two daughters and two sons.
Surviving her is her daughter, Maida Hinderlong, of the home, also one grandson.
In her active and helpful life, Mrs. Hinderlong has contributed much to the community. She will long be remembered as a wonderful friend and tireless worker in the many community projects that she helped with. She was a life-long member of Saint Peter's Evangelical and Reformed Church and faithful in her service to the church, finding her greatest joy in singing in the choir and solos. She also was a worker in the Grange to which she gave over thirty years of faithful service.
Living her entire life in the Miltonsburg community, she is remembered by all for the service she gave through the community store where she worked with her family for seventeen years. She will be greatly missed in these groups where she gave so much of her life.. May she now have heard the Master say, "Well done thou good and
 
faithful servant, enter ye into your Master's joy."
 
 
 
My Master was a worker, with daily work to do,
 
And he who would be like Him, must be a worker too.
 
Then welcome honest labor, and honest labor's fare,
 
For where there is a worker, the Master's one is there.
 
 
 
Funeral services were held Sunday afternoon, July 4th, at two o'clock in Saint Peter's Evangelical and Reformed Church at Miltonsburg, with Reverend George W. Varnes officiating. Interment was in the Miltonsburg Cemetery with the Bauer and Turner Funeral Home in charge.

HinderLong, Emma Hinderlong
June 5, 1892
Mar 1979
Sardis
HinderLong, Emma L., nee Yoss
Died: March 1, 1979
Mrs. Emma L. Hinderlong, 86, of Sardis died Thursday morning, March 1, in Marietta Memorial Hospital.
She was born June 5,1892, at Sardis, a daughter of the late Edward and Anna Elizabeth Rufener Yoss.
Mrs. Hinderlong was a member Of The Sardis Church of Christ.
She was preceded in death by her husband, Fred Hinderlong, in 1964, and a son Sterling Hinderlong, in 1977.
Surviving are a daughter, Mrs. Bernard (Elda) Wohnhas, of Sardis; one sister, Mrs. Collie Stine, of New Martinsville; one brother, Eugene Yoss, of Creston; three grandchildren, and two great grandchildren.
Funeral services were held at The Rush Funeral Home, Sardis, on Saturday afternoon at two o'clock, with Dillon Bayes officiating. Burial was in Sardis Cemetery.
 
HinderLong, Herman Hinderlong

Lewisville
Mrs. James HinderLong
Dies In The Barnesville Hospital Thursday
Published------July 1961
 
Mrs. Josephine M. HinderLong, 68, of Lewisville, Route 2, widow of James E. HinderLong
died Thursday morning, June 29, 1961, at one o'clock in The Barnesville General Hospital where she had been a patient for five days.
Mrs. HinderLong was born June 11, 1893, the daughter of Frederick and Mary Weber Neuhart, of Lewisville. She was a member of St. John's United Church of Christ at Middle Church and a lifeLong resident of Lewisville area.
Surviving are a son, Paul HinderLong, and a daughter, Miss Ruth HinderLong, of the home; two sisters, Mrs. Laura Hehr and Mrs. Clara Egger, of Lewisville, and a number of neices and nephews. Her husband, James HinderLong, died in 1935.
Short services were held at The Gardner Funeral Home on Saturday afternoon at one o'clock. Additional services were held at two o'clock in St. John's Church at Middle Church.
Rev. Donald Stump, Sr., of Lewisville, and Rev. George Corbitt, of Woodsfield, officiated. Interment was in the church cemetery.
from the collection of gertrude chrisman Kahrig typed by betty lendon matson
 
Hinderlong, Lavina

Lavina Hinderlong, 93, formerly of Egger Ridge Road, Lewisville, Monroe County, died May 9, 1984, in Samaritan Hospital, Ashland.

She was the former organist for the United Church of Christ, Miltonsburg, and was a member of St. Paul s United Church of Christ Woodsville.

She was preceded in death by her husband, Lewis Hinderlong, in 1966.

Surviving is a niece, Mrs. Ronald (Vera) Noll of Lexington.

Friends were received at the Bauer-Turner Funeral Home, Woodsfield where services were held May 12 with Rev. Gene Kraus officiating. Burial was in Oaklawn Cemetery, Woodsfield.

Memorial contributions may be made to St. Paul s United Church of Christ, 301 S. Main St. Woodsfield.

Hines, Bernice C. nee Stoffell
Source--Monroe County Beacon Woodsfield, Ohio
Published--Thursday, October 7, 2004
Bernice C. Hines, 102, Greensburg, Pennsylvania, died October 1, 2004, at Latrobe Area Hospital, Latrobe, Pennsylvania. She was born June 28, 1902, in Lewisville, a daughter of the late Phillip and Mary McVay Stoffell.
She had been a member of Hines Chapel Church of Christ, Graysville.
Surviving are two sons, Charles H. (Sally) Hines, of Pleasant Unity, Pennsylvania, Philip M. Hines, at home; two daughters, Georgia Taylor, of San Diego, California, Hazel Palmer, of Greensburg; 21 grandchildren; 46 great-grandchildren; 10 great-great-grandchildren; sister Wilma Lafferee of Columbus, several nieces and nephews.
In addition to her parents, she was preceded in death by her husband George H. Hines; daughter Helen Richardson; two sisters, Freida Knupp, Wava Wilhelm.
Friends were received at Gaut-Bacha Funeral Home, Pleasant Unity, October 3, where funeral services were held October 4, with Reverend David J. Ackerman officiating. Burial followed in Hillview Cemetery, Greensburg.
 
Hines, Burris
Died: May 15, 1922
 
Hines, Carol and Yvonne

June 12, 1975

The Monroe County Beacon, Woodsfield, Ohio

Two former residents of Woodsfield, Carol and Yvonne Hines, have joined together in establishing a new business venture, the Travel Hut of Hauppauge, New York.

Both women bring to the Travel Agency business a thorough background in the travel field. Yvonne previously worked with Overseas National Airways as a stewardess for two years based in New York. Carol previously worked with Trans World Airlines for nine years; four years as a stewardess, three as a stewardess supervisor, and two yeas a Director of Customer Service. They have both traveled extensively throughout the world, Yvonne having temporarily lived in the Middle East and Mexico.

The two sisters are the daughters of Mrs. Betty L. Hines and the late Leonard T. Hines, of 107 South Paul Street, Woodsfield, Ohio.

The mother, Mrs. Betty Hines, of Woodsfield, is attending the grand opening of the Travel Hut on June 12, in New York.

 

 
Hines, Clara Gertrude (nee Bintz)
Mrs. Clara Bintz Hines of Bucyrus, Ohio formerly of Lewisville, Ohio died January 6, 1982 in the Bucyrus Hospital.
She was born January 1, 1895 in Monroe County, a daughter of the late George and Anna Ackerman Bintz.
Mrs. Hines was a member of the Epworth United Methodist Church at Bucyrus.
Her husband George Hines preceded her in death September 13, 1959.
Surviving are two daughters, Mrs. Hazel Christman and Mrs. Mary Kocher both of Bucyrus, three sisters, Esta Taylor of Bucyrus, Freda Clegg of Wheeling, WV and Viola Christman of Quaker City, five grandchildren.
Friends were received at the Bauer-Turner Funeral Home in Woodsfield Friday from 7 to 9 p.m.
Services were held Saturday at l:00 p.m. with Rev. E. Parker West of Bucyrus officiating. Burial was in Oakland Cemetery at Woodsfield, Ohio.

Hines, John A.
We are sorry that we have to pen the sad news of John Almon Hines which occurred at his home in Lewisville, Ohio last Thursday night, August 28, 1913, of complications of diseases and was buried at St. John s Middle Church in Summit township, last Saturday morning, it being one of the largest funerals ever held at the Middle church. He was born July 8, 1867. He leaves his devoted wife Elizabeth Matz Hines, and three sons. He lived on the ridge for several years before moving to Lewisville and will be missed by many of his friends. Farewell, John, only a few short years and we will meet beyond the clouds, beyond the tomb; there is no night, no parting tear are shed. Oh! Grave, where is thy victory, Oh! , where is thy sting. May his soul rest in peace.
Source:The Monroe Republican, Woodsfield, Ohio, August 1913
Collection of Ralph E. Matz

Hinkle, Phyllis T., nee Thomas
Woodsfield, Ohio- Phyllis T. Hinkle, 62, of Woodsfield, died Friday Sept. 22, 2000 at Barnesville Hospital.
She was born Aug. 9, 1938, in Clarington, daughter of the late Cedric and Nora (Stewart) Thomas.
She was preceded in death by a son, Thomas Hinkle; and a brother, Cedric Jake Thomas. She leaves her husband, Elson Lee Hinkle Jr., of the home; two sons, Elson Lee (Marilyn) Hinkle III and James Thomas, both of Woodsfield; three sisters, Barbara McGee and Dolly Huff of, both of Shadyside and Helen Huntsman of Barnesville; four grandchildren; several nieces and nephews.
Friends may call from 2 to 3 p.m. Tuesday at Watters Funeral Home, Woodsfield, with services to follow at 3 p.m., with the Revs. William Graham and Lloyd Hill officiating. Burial will be held at the convenience of the family.

Hoff, Mrs. Anna (nee Young)

Source: Monroe County Beacon

Mrs. Anna B. Young Hoff, 74, former resident of the Lewisville community, died Monday evening, April 1st, at 6:30 o'clock, at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Laura Weber, at Quaker City, after an extended illness. She was born in Summit Township, near Lewisville.

Surviving are one son, Ernest Hoff, of Lewisville Route 2; three daughters, Mrs. Wesley Weber, of Lewisville Route 2; Mrs. Arthur Reich, of Woodsfield, Route 3 and Mrs. Laura Weber, of Quaker Ciity at whose home she died; fifteen grandchildren; seven great grandchildren, and one brother John Young, of Nashville, Tennessee. Her husband Lewis Hoff, died several years ago.

Mrs. Hoff was a member of the Evangelical and Reformed Church.

Friends will be received at the Bauer and Turner Funeral Home in Woodsfield until noon Thursday when the body will be taken in St. Peter's Evangelical and Reformed Church in Lewisville to lie in state until time for services at two o'clock. Rev. George W. Varns will officiate. Interment will be in the Miltonsburg Cemetery.

Hoff, Eileen Louise

1954

MARRIAGE

Source: Monroe County Beacon

Mr. and Mrs. Ernest F. Hoff, of Lewisville, are announcing the approaching marriage of their third daughter, Eileen Louise, to William W. Wise, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. G. Wise of Belmont.

The wedding be an event of Sunday, February fourteenth, and will take place in St. Peter's Evangelical and Reformed Church at Lewisville, at half after eight o'clock in the evening. The Rev. George Varns will officiate at the double ring ceremony. The custom of "open church" will be observed.

 
Hoff, Eva Matilda (nee Smith)
Mrs. George Hoff
Published --April 1956
Mrs. George Hoff, 85, of Lewisville, died Thursday morning, March 29, at three o'clock
in Bethesda Hospital, Zanesville.
She was born June 21, 1893, in Monroe County, a daughter of the late George and Mary Young Smith.
Mrs. Hoff was a member of The Lewisville United Methodist Church. Her husband , George Hoff, preceded her in , April 6, 1956.
Surviving are one daughter, Mrs. Harry (Clara) Matz of Lewisville; one grandson; four great grandchildren; one great great grandchild; three sisters, Mrs. Mary Schneider of Merrill, Wis.; Mrs. Frda Smith of Dalton and Mrs. Lyria Kestner of Massillion, and four brothers; Henry Smith of Lewisville; Charles Smith and Elmer Smith of Dalton and Fred Smith of Summerfield.
Funeral services were held Saturday afternoon at two o'clock at the Bauer and Turner Funeral Home, Woodsfield, with Rev. Randy Cetorelli officiating. Burial was in Friendship Cemetery, Lewisville.

, 1912
Hoff, Fred
Fred Hoff an old and highly respected citizen of Monroe County died at the home of his son-in-law Philip ZERGER, in Malaga twp., on Saturday evening. Mr. Hoff s wife died about two years ago and later Mr. Hoff went to Stark County, Ohio to live with his son, F. W. Hoff. About two weeks ago he came back to Monroe County on a visit. He was not well when he arrived and continued to grow worse until came. Mr. Hoff leaves to mourn his one son and three daughters, besides other relatives and a large circle of friends. Mr. Hoff was a member of the Evangelical Church and the funeral was held Tuesday afternoon and interment made in the Miltonsburg Evangelical cemetery, Miltonsburg, Ohio.
Source:newspaper clipping, 1912

Hoff, Helen V.
Helen V. Hoff, (Grandma) 95, of Woodsfield, Ohio, died Sunday, January 9, 2005, at Barnesville Hospital, Barnesville, Ohio. She was born September 27, 1909, at Sistersville, West Virginia, a daughter of the late George McClelland Campbell and Annie Jane Edinger Campbell.
She wa a member of Saint Paul s United Church of Christ, Woodsfield, where she had been the church organist for many years. She was also a member of Eastern Star and Charter member of Women of the Moose Logde, of Woodsfield.
Surviving are two sons, Joe (Chris) Hoff, Woodsfield, John (Wanda) Hoff, Woodsfield; daughter Jane (Richard) Radon, of Scottsboro, Alabama; seven grandchildren, Taren (Mike) Dawson, Stacy (Christy) Radon, Casey Hoff, Kevin Hoff, Lisa (Tye) Schwall, April Hoff and Jessica Hoff; five great-grandchildren, Megan Radon, Alexis Dawson, Garytt Schwall, Douglas Hoff and Breannon Hoff.
In Addition to her parents, she was preceded in death by her husband, Charles W. Hoff in 1983; three brothers, Ralph, Frank and Charles Campbell.
Friends were received January 11 at Bauer-Turner Funeral Home, Woodsfield, where services will be held January 12, at 11 a.m., with the Reverend Father Chester Pabin officiating. Burial in Oaklawn Cemetery, Woodsfield. Source: Monroe County Beacon, Thursday, January 13, 2005.
 

Hoff, Laura Weber, Gildea

Mrs. Laura Weber Gildea, nee Hoff, 66, of Quaker City, died Friday morning in Barnesville Hospital.

She was born Aug. 11, 1909 in Monroe County.

Surviving are two sons, Lyle of Loudonville and Lesli of Frazeysburg; five grandsons and a great-grandson; six step-children; several step grandchildren; and a sisters Melva G. Reich of Woodsfield Route 3.

The body is at Eberle Funeral Home in Quaker City, where services will beheld at 1 pm. Monday. Burial will be in Middle Church Cemetery. Friends may call 7 to 9 p.m. today and 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. Sunday.

Hoffman, Cecil E. Residence: Woodsfield enlistment: 1918 Jul 15 b.p.: Woodsfield born: 1893 Mar 30
Hoffman, Mr. Otto R. and Miss Freda Seebach
On Saturday morning, April 7, 1917, at six o clock Miss Freda Seebach was united in marriage to Mr. Ott R. HoffMAN of Akron, Ohio. The ceremony was performed at the parsonage by the Reverend A. H. Knipping, pastor of St. Paul s Evangelical Church, in the presence of a few close friends. Immediately following the ceremony and congratulations the young people and their friends took the morning train for Lewisville where a hearty welcome awaited them at the Seebach home, the family having recently moved from Woodsfield to that place.
Source: The Spirit of Democracy, Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, April 19, 1917.
 
May 2, 1923
Hoffmeister, Miss Bessie M. and Mr. Clemence J. Stegner
Source: newspaper clipping, 1909
Collection of Wilda Heft Bartenschlag
Clemence J. STEGNER and energetic and ambitious young oil man of Lewisville, Ohio and Miss Bessie M. HoffMEISTER, an estimable young lady of Miltonsburg, Ohio were married at the home of Mr. and Mrs. John Nalley of South Paul Street, Woodsfield, Ohio on Wednesday evening, June 9, 1909. Reverend A. A. MULLER performed the ceremony.
After a trip to Niagara Falls and other Eastern points of interest the young couple will go to housekeeping at Lewisville. They have the best wishes of many friends including the Courier.

Hogue, Marjorie M.
Source:Marietta Times . . . Marietta, OH . . Jan 2002
Provided by Betty Lendon Matson
Woodsfield - Marjorie M. Hogue, 80, of 36920 Ohio 78, Woodsfield, died at 7:40 a.m. Wednesday (January 30, 2002) at the Woodsfield Nursing and Rehabilitation Center in Woodsfield.
She was born February 9, 1921, at Woodsfield to Vernon Maurice and Bertha Kinsey Nalley. She was a homemaker and was a member of the Woodsfield Church of Christ.
She is survived by two daughters, Bonnie Rothenbuhler of Cameron, Ohio, and Sharon Weber and her husband, Don, of Woodsfield; one son, Gailord Hogue and his wife, Laura, of Woodsfield; seven grandchildren; and 12 great-grandchildren.
She was preceded in death by her husband, Ellis E. Hogue, on June 18, 1999; her parents; two brothers, James Nalley and Melvin Nalley; and two grandsons, Jeffrey Hogue and Jon Garrett Hogue.
Services are at 11 a.m. Saturday at Watters Funeral Home, 37501 Ohio 78 West, Woodsfield, with Sam Bartrug officiating. Burial is in Oaklawn Cemetery in Woodsfield. Friends will be received from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. Friday at the funeral home.

Hogue, Norman G.
 
September 22, 1920
 
Mar 25, 1997
 
Woodsfield
 
Hogue, Rosena Faye Anderson,
In everybody s garden a little rain must fall
Or Life s sweetest, fairest flowers
wouldn t grow and bloom at all;
 
And though the clouds hang heavy,
so heavy, Oh my friend,
I m sure that God who sends the shower
will send the rainbow s end.
Rosena Faye (Hogue) Anderson, only daughter of Leland R. and Mary (Cline) Hogue, was born near Woodsfield, Ohio, on March 28, 1928, and departed this life on December 22, 1951, being at the time of her , 23 years, 8 months and 24 days of age. On January 10, 1948, she was united in marriage with Alexander D. Anderson, of Newark, Ohio, and to this union was born one son, Danny Lee Anderson.
Besides her husband and little son, she is survived by her parents, Leland R. and Mary E. Hogue, and three brothers, Pfc. Larry R. Hogue, of Fort Hood, Texas, and Bobby and Keith Hogue of the family home in Newark, Ohio; also a large number of other relatives and friends.
While yet a small child she was baptized at the Bracken Methodist Church near Lewisville, Ohio, and remained true to her faith in God and the Church. She was always in Church as Long as her health would permit, and always took an active part in the work. Rosena was educated in the Monroe County schools, having attended school at both Lewisville and Woodsfield. She moved with her family to Newark, Ohio, seven years ago, where the remainder of her life was spent.
Rosena was gifted with a wonderful personality and many will remember the numerous occasions when she sang in the Church and at many other religious meetings. From childhood, she was gifted with musical talent, which she greatly enjoyed as Long as her health would permit. She was always ready and eager to help those who were less fortunate than herself. She was especially helpful to her loved ones and in the home. Her going leaves an emptiness that this world can never fill. She will not only be missed in the immediate home, but by a large number of relatives and friends to whom she had endeared herself as the wonderful person that she was.
Three years ago she was stricken by the fatal disease, which slowly but surely, sapped her life away. All that loving hands and medical skill could do, was done, but to no avail, and she quietly slipped away from this world of pain and sorrow to an unseen world to us.
Short funeral services were held at the home in Newark, on Wednesday morning, December 26, at 9:30 o clock with the Reverend H. E. Doyle, of the Pine Street C. U. Church, officiating, after which the funeral cortege left for the Bracken Methodist Church near Lewisville, where final services were held at 2:00 with the Reverend Fontella Linn, of Lewisville, officiating.
Interment was made in the Bracken Ridge cemetery by the Criss Brothers Funeral directors of Newark.
Source: The Monroe County Beacon, Woodsfield, Ohio, December, 1951
Provided by Wilda Heft Bartenschlag
 
Hogue, Miss Sharon Kay and Donald W. Weber

June 30, 1966

Source: Monroe County Beacon

Miss Sharon Kay Hogue, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ellis Hogue of Route 3, Woodsfield, became the bride of Mr. Donald W. Weber, son of Mr. and Mrs. Willard Weber, of Lewisville, Route 1, Saturday, June fourth, at two o'clock in the afternoon at the Church Christ in Woodsfield.

Minister John Hamilton officiated at the double ring ceremony before an altar beautifully decorated with flowers.

Classmates Sally Kehrig, Janet Winland, Peggy Mahoney and Sandra Berry, accompanied by John Eye, sang "I Love Your Truly" and "Oh Promise Me."

Given in marriage by her father, the bride was attired in a floor length gown of white acetate nylon lace over taffeta styled with a fitted bodice a scalloped sabrina neckline and iridescent sequin trim. Her veil was a pillbox style of applique silk with seeded pearls. She carried a white Bible with a lace covering, topped with a bouquet of pink and white camillias and white satin streamers.

Maid of honor was the bride's sister, Miss Bonnie Hogue, of Woodsfield, Her gown was a floor length empire style of powder blue soft sheet georgette misted over acetate taffeta, with a jacket of nylon lace. She carried a colonial bouquet of blue and white carnations with satin streamers.

Miss Carolyn McCammon, cousin of the bride, and Miss Penny Platt, of Woodsfield, were bridesmaids.' They wore gowns identical to the maid of honor's the gowns being of light green and pale pink shades. They carried colonial bouquets of carnations with satin streamers.

Miss Lelanda Sue Wiley of Woodsfield, friend of the bride, was flower girl, and Michael Hogue, nephew of the bride, was ring bearer.

Dale Weber, of Columbus, served his brother as best man. Ushers were Charles McCammon and Dale Rothenbuhler, friends of the bridegroom.

The bride's mother was attired in a pink silk shantung suit with pink and white accessories and a corsage of pink carnations.

The bridegroom's mother wore a green linen and lace dress with beige accessories and a corsage of yellow carnations.

Miss Sharon Henthorn, of Woodsfield, was in charge of the guest book. Out of town guests were from Barnesville, Bolivar, Zanesville, Newark, Columbus, Lewisville, and Cameron.

Immediately following the ceremony, a reception was held at the Henri Coulson Building. Aides were Mrs. Mildred Christman, Mrs. Ruth Graham and Mrs. Carol Hogue.

Hohman, Thelma C.
Source:Canton Repository . . Canton, OH . . 3 Mar 2001
Provided by Betty Lendon Matson
Thelma C. Hohman, age 76, of Canton, died Friday morning in the HaNovemberer House after an extended illness. Born in Lewisville, OH, (daughter of William J. Yontz and Nellie G. Ritterbeck) she had been a Canton resident since 1947. She retired in 1985 from the J.C. Penney Co. after 19 years of service. She was a member of St. Joan of Arc Catholic Church, St. Joan of Arc Altar Rosary Society, St. Joan of Arc Sewing Club and the A.A.R.P. Survived by her husband, Charles W. Hohman; three daughters and two sons-in-law, Carol and David Phillips of Canton, Arlene Watters of Coroapolis, PA and Joyce and Gary Isler of North Canton; a son and daughter-in-law, Ken and Polly Hohman of Copley, OH; seven grandchildren, Mark Wootton, Lori Laghaeian, Jenny Shaver, Jason Watters, Jessica Hohman, and Chad and Kari Isler; two great-grandchildren, Aidan Laghaeian and Ashley Wootton; and four brothers, Joe Yontz of North Canton, Ray Yontz of Jerusalem, OH, Dale Yontz of Woodsfield, OH and Ronald Yontz of Canton. Preceded in death by two sisters, Leona and Bertha Michel; and a son-in-law, Michael Watters. A Mass of Christian Burial will be Monday at 10 a.m. in St. Joan of Arc Catholic Church with Fr. Thomas P. Dyer as celebrant. Burial will be in Calvary Cemetery. Friends may call Sunday 2-5 p.m. at the Lamiell Funeral Home. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to a charity of your choice.

Holiday, Hester M. Leasure
Hester M. Leasure nee Holiday
 
Hester M. Leasure, 69, of 910 Belford St., Caldwell, died October 18, 2000, in the Riverside Methodist Hospital, Columbus. She was born near Graysville, June 21,1931, a daughter of the late Velma Isabelle Wise Holiday. She was a former seamtress for L.G.A.M. Manufacturing in Woodsfield, and a member of the former Mt. Tabor Methodist Church, near Summerfield. She was also a former member of the Franklin Homemakers Club near Lewisville.
 
Surviving are her husband, Junior E. Leasure, whom she married May 6, 1950; six daughters, Mrs.Ronnie (Irene) Tidd, Newport, Mrs. Rodney (Darlene) Bettinger, Donna Bennett, Delaware, Mrs. Hank (Debbie) Williams, Marietta, Kandi McQueary, Marietta, Mrs. Rodney (Michele) Nichols, Beverly; a son, Shawn Leasure, of the home; a sister, Nancy Tidd, Lower Salem; two brothers, Roger Holiday, Lowell, Robert Holiday, Whipple; two step-sisters, Linda Holiday, Sycamore Valley, Marion Block, Pennsylvania; two half-sisters, Mary Carpenter, Port Washington, Ada Offenberger, Whipple; 16 grandchildren; 14 great-grandchildren; several nieces and nephews and close friends.
 
In addition to her mother, she was preceded in death by a daughter, Joyce Goff; a brother, Eugene Holiday; a step-father, Cecil Holiday.
 
Friends were received at the Watter's Funeral Home, Woodsfield, October 21, 2000, where funeral services were held October 22, with Dana Morrison officiating. Burial followed in Mt. Tabor Cemetery, near Summerfield.

Holliday, Florence E. Holliday
 
Aug 29, 1914
 
June 11, 2000
 
Woodsfield
 
Holliday, Nancy Lee Tidd
Nancy Lee Tidd, 61, of Highland Ridge Road, died early Tuesday (Nov. 23, 2004) at her home.
She was born Oct. 4, 1943, at Graysville, Ohio, a daughter of Cecil and Velma Wise Holiday. She had spent most of her life in the Whipple and Lower Salem area, and was a graduate of Salem-Liberty High School. She had been affiliated with the Home Nursing Service and enjoyed collecting cow figurines and attending yard sales. She was a former member of the Ladies of the Moose and was a member of the Open Door Baptist Church.
She was married to Thomas Richard Tidd, who preceded her in death. She is survived by her daughters, Tammy (Brian) Sturm, Nancy Spencer, Thomas (Beverly) Tidd, John (Diane) Russell, and Brad (Brenda) Russell; her long time companion for the past 21 years, John F. Russell; and her grandchildren, Ross Phillip, Sylvia Russell, Cammy Jo Spencer, Mike Russell, Holly Phillip, Johnny Russell, Tommy Spencer, Christopher Sturm, Kayla Tidd, Shelby Ingram, Kristen Long, Tyler Spencer, and Trenten Spencer. She is also survived by one brother, Roger (Sue) Holiday of Lowell; two half sisters, Mary (Kim) Carpenter of Port Washington and Ada (Dale) Offenberger of Whipple; two stepsisters, Marion (Charlie) Block of Edensburg, Pa. and Linda Holiday of Sycamore Valley. In addition to her parents and her husband, she was preceded in death by her stepmother, Mary Emma Holiday; one sister, Hester May Leasure; two brothers, Gene and Bob Holiday; and a daughter, Emma Gale Tidd. She is survived by several nephews and nieces, including Cheryl Blankenship of Newport, and was partially reared by her aunt, Nancy Lee Tidd.
Funeral services will be held at 11 a.m. Saturday at the McClure-Schafer-Lankford Funeral Home with Pastor Keith Kappel officiating. Burial will be in Newport Cemetery. Friends may call at the funeral home from 2 p.m. Friday until the hour of the service.
Source: Marietta Times, Wednesday, November 24, 2004.

Hook, Jennie Louise (Gatten)
Source:Times Recorder . . Zanesville, OH . . . 2 Apr 2002
Provided by Betty Lendon Matson
Zanesville, Ohio-- Jennie Louise Hook, 83, of 1136 Adair Ave., died at 6:30 p.m. Saturday, March 30, 2002, at Cedar Hill Care Center.
Born January 3, 1919, in Woodsfield, she was formerly employed at Hazel-Atlas, Essex Wire and Mosaic Tile Co. and was a Protestant by faith.
Surviving are her husband, Paul Hook; a son, Harold (Carolyn) Merola Sr. of Zanesville; a daughter, Elizabeth (William) Miller of Zanesville; seven grandchildren, Angie (Jeff) Fuller, Amy (Jamie) Krouskoupf, Jake Merola, Doreen (Ron) Wise, Tina (Tom) Campbell, Billy (Denise) Miller Jr. and Penny (Darren) Phillips; 14 great-grandchildren; and four great-great-grandchildren.
She was preceded in death by her parents, Oliver and Ethel Poulton Gatten; and four brothers, Harry, Cecil, George and Joseph Gatten.
Calling hours will be 2 to 4 and 6 to 8 p.m. today at DeLong-Baker & Lanning Funeral Home, 56 S. Fifth St.
Services will be held at 1 p.m. Wednesday at the funeral home with Pastor Keith Lingsch officiating. Burial will be in Greenwood Cemetery.

Hooper, Roxie F. Weddle
Roxie F. Weddle, 83, 35335 Cronin Creek Road, Woodsfield, died January 30, 2005 at her residence. She was born at Mechanicsburg, on October 6, 1921, a daughter of the late Howard and Martha Cline Hooper.
She was a former cook at he former Wayne School and was a retired caregiver at the Monroe County Home, Woodsfield. She was a member of the Huffman Grange and a Protestant by faith.
Surviving are her husband, Wiley Weddle, whom she married October 27, 1941; a daughter, Bonnie (Gary) Reed; son, Clayton "bud" (Cindy) Weddle, both of Woodsfield; two sisters, Elsie Butler, Woodsfield, Lucy (James) Blake, Beach bottom, West Virginia; five half-sisters, Mable Belford, of Zanesville, Alice (Bob) Saint Clair, of Senecaville, Connie (John) Eddy, of Zanesville, Norman Jean (William) Dale, of Gratiot, Mildred Kinney, of Michigan; six grandchildren; three great-grandchildren.
In addition to her parents, she was preceded in death by her step-mother, Hilda Dillon; son, Richard Wiley Weddle; brother, Charles Hooper.
Friends were received at Watters Funeral Home, Woodsfield, February 1, where services will be held February 2, at 11 a.m., with Keith Jones officiating. Burial in Jericho cemetery, near Brownsville. Huffman Grange conducted services February 1 at the funeral home.
Source: Monroe County Beacon, Thursday, February 3, 2005.

Hopton, Blanche
Blanche Hopton, 87, Woodsfield, Ohio, died Tuesday, at the Monroe County Care Center. She was born Jan. 1, 1917 in Belmont, County, daughter of the late Oliver and Thurza (Neptune) Mayberry.
She was a member of Somerton United Methodist Church where she was pianist and organist for 40 years.
In addition to her parents, she was preceded in death by a sister, Rosanna Wheatley and a brother, Charles Nelson Mayberry.
Surviving are a daughter, Helen (Allen) Wilcox of Somerton, Ohio; two sisters, Jennie (Dick) Huntsman of Barnesville, and Mildred Abel of Canton, Ohio; two grandchildren and five great grandchildren.
Visitation, Thursday, 4 to 8 with services at 11 a.m., Friday at the Campbell-Plumly-Milburn Funeral Home, 319 N. Chestnut St., Barnesville, Ohio, with Rev. Rusty Atkinson officiating. Burial follows in Somerton Cemetery.
Memorials may be made to the Somerton United Methodist Church or Somerton Volunteer Fire Department. Source: Times Leader, Thursday, October 21, 2004
 
Hopton, Maud E. (Mobley)
Source:Marietta Times . .Marietta, OH . . June 2001 . .
Provided by Betty Lendon Matson
Maud E. Hopton, 89, of Pfalzgraf Road, formerly of Flint, Mich., died Sunday (June 24, 2001) at the Woodsfield Nursing and Rehabilitation Center.
She was born June 6, 1912, in Monroe County to Charles F. and Elizabeth Agin Mobley. She retired from the J.C. Penney Co. at Bay City, Mich. She was a member of Woodsfield Church of Christ and also the Church of Christ in Flint.
She is survived by two sons, Richard Hopton and his wife, Betty, of Woodsfield and Ronald Hopton and his wife, Sandra, of Gaines, Mich.; two daughters, Carolyn Roe and her husband, Sam, of Flint and Marilyn Herman and her husband, Gordon, of Evart, Mich.; one daughter-in-law, Dorothy Hopton of Flushing; two sisters, Gladys Haynes of Rittman and Pearl Piatt of Woodsfield; 12 grandchildren; 19 great-grandchildren; four stepgreat-grandchildren; and two great-great-grandchildren.
She was preceded in death by her husband, John E. Hopton, in 1992; one son, Denzel Hopton; her parents; one sister, Lucy Simmons; one brother, Charles A. Mobley; two grandchildren, Barbara Ann Hopton and Vicki West; and two great-grandchildren, Reid Hopton and Maranda Roe.
Services are at 10 a.m. Wednesday at Bauer-Turner Funeral Home, 100 S. Paul St., Woodsfield, with Keith Jones officiating. Burial is in Oaklawn Cemetery in Woodsfield. Friends will be received from 4 to 9 p.m. today at the funeral home.
 
Horner, James R. "Huji"
Source--News Register Wheeling, West Virginia
Published--July 2000
James R. "Huji" Horner, of Pensacola, Florida, formerly of Smithfield, West Virginia, died Thursday, July 20,2000,at home. He was retired from the former Hope Natural Gas Company., Hastings, West Virginia, a member of the Church of Christ, Smithfield, West Virginia, and an Army veteran of World War II, where he received a Purple Heart. He was preceded in death by his parents, James Lee and Priscilla Belle Adams Horner; four brothers, Clyde, John, Gilbert "Gib" and Bernard Horner; and a sister, Amanda Shreve. Surviving are his wife, Leora Irene Barr Horner; two sons, Ronald "Ron" of Smithfield and Kenny Horner of Woodsfield, Ohio; a daughter, Jan Johnson of Pensacola, Florida; a sister, Josephine Hall of Louisville, Kentucky; and three grandchildren, James Daniel Horner of Smithfield, Bryan and Lora Horner both of Woodsfield. Friends received 2-9 p.m. Sunday at Palmer Funeral Home, Pine Grove, West Virginia where services will be held at 11 a.m., Monday. Interment in Mannington Memorial, Mannington, West Virginia.
Source: Sunday News-Register, Wheeling, West Virginia - July 2000)
Horner, John R.
Source--Wetzel County Message Board West Virginia
Published--December 1988
John R. Horner, Sr., 62 of Pine Grove, died Tuesday, December 20, 1988, in Reynolds Memorial Hospital, Glen Dale. He was a retired employee of Consolidated Gas Supply Corporation , Hastings, a member of the Pine Grove Church of Christ and a Navy Veteran of World War II. Surviving are his wife, Madge Bland Horner; a son, John R. Jr., of Pine Grove; a daughter, Kathy Horner of Clarington, Ohio; three brothers, Bernard of McMechen, James of Smithfield, West Virginia and Gilbert Gib of Pine Grove; two sisters, Josephine Hall of Louisville, Kentucky and Amanda Shreve of Smithfield, West Virginia; two grandchildren. Friends received at Palmer Funeral Home where services were held. Interment in Knights of Pythias Cemetery, Pine Grove, Wetzel County, West Virginia.
 
Horvath, Vera J.
Born: September 26, 1931, died: May 9, 2003, residence:Beallsville, Ohio
 
Hosery, Shirley Kuhn, nee Hosery
Shirley J. Kuhn, 67, of State Route 145, Lewisville, Ohio, died Monday, April 5, 2004 at the Woodsfield Nursing and Rehabilitation Center, Woodsfield, Ohio, following a short battle with Autoimmune (PBC) Liver Disease.
She was born near Sutton, West Virginia on March 26, 1937, a daughter of the late Ralph M. and Lois I. Peters Hosery.
 
She was a homemaker and a member of St. Joseph Catholic Church near Lewisville, Ohio, where she was also a member of the Catholic Women's Club and a past member of the Ladies Auxiliary of the Lewisville Fire Department, Lewisville, Ohio.
 
In addition to her parents, she was preceded in death by one brother, Tom Hosey.
 
Surviving are her husband, Kenneth Eugene Kuhn whom she married on Feb. 16, 1957; one daughter, Kristina K. Lafferre and her husband, Kevin of Lewisville, Ohio; two sons: Mark A. Kuhn of Hannibal, Ohio and Brian E. Kuhn and his wife, Kay, of Lewisville, Ohio; three sisters, Gay Egger of Riverside, California, Ruth Bates of Las Vegas, Nevada and Rebecca Bautista of Corona, California; five brothers: Harold Hosey, Isaac Hosey and Luther Hosey, all of Webster Springs, West Virginia, Ralph Hosey of Diamond, Ohio and Albert "Puz" Hosey of Medina, Ohio; five grandchildren: Kristy, Dustin and Morgan Kuhn, Trent and Lynsey Lafferre; several brother and sister-in-laws and nieces and nephews.
Friends will be received at the St. Joseph Catholic Church near Lewisville, Ohio from 5 to 8 p.m., Wednesday. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at 8 p.m., Wednesday, at the church with Rev. Fr. David Gaydosik as the celebrant.
Interment will be held at 10 a.m., Thursday, at St. Joseph Catholic Cemetery, near Lewisville, Ohio.
Memorial contributions may be made to St. Joseph Catholic Church or to the St. Joseph Catholic Women's Club, 334 S. main Street, Woodsfield, Ohio 43793 or to the Lewisville Volunteer Fire Dept., P. O. Box 115, Lewisville, Ohio 43754.
Arrangements by Watters Funeral Home, Woodsfield, Ohio

Hossman, Benjamin E.
Hossman, Benjamin E. , 72, of 1953 Grandview Road, Glen Dale, died Friday at 9:05 a.m. at Reynolds Memorial Hospital. He was born April 6, 1898, at Sardis,O., son of Godfrey and Lena Rusener Hossman. He was a carpenter-contractor, founder of The Hossman Contracting Co.; member of Pleasant Hill Methodist Church; Carpenters Local No.3.
Surviving are his widow, Ellen Hinerman Hossman; a son, Dale B., Glen Dale; a daughter, Mrs. Ralph (Rosalie) Cain, Glen Dale Heights; seven grandchildren; six step-children; seventeen step-grandchildren; two sisters, Mrs. Everett (Ella) Jones, McMechen; Mrs. Midge Long, Cobb Island,Md.; two brothers,George, St. Clairsville; Ernest, Glen Dale Heights.

Hossman, Freda Claus

November 5, 1986

The Monroe County Beacon, Woodsfield, Ohio

Freda L. Claus, nee Hossman

Freda L. (Hossman) Claus, 87, died Oct. 24, at Akron City Hospital. Mrs. Claus was born in Malaga, but lived most her life in Akron. During the past 35 years, she lived in Melbourne, FL part of the year.

She was preceded in death by her husband, Walter C. Claus, eight brothers and one sister and one grandson.

She is survived by two daughters, Mrs. C. Edward (Evelyn) Reed of Akron, Mrs. Grace Jones of Atwater; one son, Wilbert of Lewisville; eight grandsons and 12 great-grandchildren.

Services were held Oct. 27 at 2:30 p.m. from Hopkins Lawyer Funeral Home, Akron. Burial in Hillside Memorial Park.

Householder, Richard
Source--Toothman Memorial Obituaries Saint Clairsville, Ohio
Published--February 16, 2005
Householder , Richard Eugene , 43 formerly of Belmont Habilitation Center in Saint Clairsville died Monday, February 14, 2005 at Ohio Valley Medical Center in Wheeling. This special child was born on July 30, 1961 to Gary E. Householder and Sheila Clark Householder of Woodford, Virginia. He was preceded in death by his paternal grandparents, Carl and Gladys Householder; maternal grandparents, Robert and Lena Clark; infant sister, Sheila Householder. Surviving in addition to his parents, are two sisters, Barbara Mazzella of Laurel, Delaware and Penny Ashley of Woodford, Virginia; 1 nephew, 2 nieces, numerous aunts, uncles, and cousins. Friends will be received on Wednesday from 2 to 4 & 7 to 9 p.m. at the Toothman Funeral Home in Saint Clairsville where services will be held at 11 a.m. on Thursday, February 17, 2005 with Reverend Jerry Wenger officiating. Burial follows in Guernsey Memory Gardens, Cambridge, Ohio.

Howell, Clarence G. "Dutch"
Source--Daily Jeffersonian Cambridge, Ohio
Published---January 2001
 
WOODSFIELD Howell,Clarence G. Dutch , 74, of Moore Ridge Road, Jerusalem, died Wednesday (Jan. 24, 2001) at The Ohio State University Hospital, Columbus.
He was born October 31, 1926, in Wayne County, son of the late Andrew and Ova Myers Howell.
He retired from Labor Union 639, Marietta, and he was a retired farmer, a member of the Church of Christ and a veteran of the Korean War.
He was preceded in death by a daughter, Ruth Ellen Howell; two sisters, Evelyn Malcuit and Margaret Mann; a brother, Robert Howell.
Mr. Howell leaves his wife of 50 years, Dorothy Gallaher Howell of Jerusalem; four daughters, Mary Annn (John) Yontz of Ozark, Helen (Rocky) Carpenter of Barnesville, Jean (Richard) Hughes of Jerusalem, and Connie (Larry) Richter of Sardis; four brothers, John, Jack and George Howell, all of Orrville and Vernon Howell of Apple Creek; seven grandchildren.
Friends may call from 2 to 9 p.m. today at Bauer-Turner Funeral Home, 100 S. Paul St., Woodsfield, where services will be 1 p.m. Saturday. Minister John Hamilton will officiate.
Burial will be in Ozark Catholic Cemetery.
