Howell, Edith J., nee Lancaster
Source--Wetzel County Message Board West Virginia
Published--February 2004
Edith J. Howell, 80, of New Martinsville, West Virginia died Friday, February 27, 2004 in the New Martinsville Health Care Center in New Martinsville.
She was born January 1, 1924 at Wileyville a daughter of the late Samuel Lancaster and Lela Postlethwait Lancaster.
Mrs. Howell was a homemaker. She was a member of the First Church of God of New Martinsville and also a member of the WCG of the First Church of God.
Surviving are three sons, Gary D. Howell and Ronald W. Howell, both of Hundred, and Larry E. Howell of Walland, Tennessee; two daughters, Joyce L. Smith of New Martinsville and Donna K. Hess of Powhatan Point, Ohio; one brother, Edward E. Lancaster of New Martinsville; sixteen grandchildren and twelve great-grandchildren.
In addition to her parents she was preceded in death by her husband, Jesse W. Howell; an infant daughter, Carolyn Howell; one sister, Pearl Freeman, and one brother Philmore Lancaster.
Friends may call at the Tennant Funeral Home in Hundred from 6-9 p.m. Monday. Funeral services will be held in the funeral home at 11:00 Tuesday. Interment will follow in the Paden Memorial Gardens in Paden City, West Virginia.

Howiler, Jacob
Died: March 6, 1914
 
Howiler, Joanna (nee Warner)
After several years of declining health and confined to a wheel chair most of the time, Mrs. Joanna Howiler, passed away in her home on Greenmount Ave. Sunday afternoon at 3:40. She had been seriously ill and confined to her bed the past few weeks.
Deceased, a daughter of James W. and Mary Carpenter Warner was born January. 12, 1859 in Noble County, but had been a resident of Barnesville for many years and was a member of the West Main St. Church of Christ. She was highly respected a good neighbor and hospitable in her home.
She was the widow of Benjamin F. Howiler who preceded her in death several years ago, but she is survived by one daughter; Mrs. Jessie Cole, Barnesville; one son Frank Howiler, Akron; six grandchildren, twenty great-grandchildren; two step-sons, Joseph Howiler, Barnesville; John Howiler, Akron. She also leaves four brothers and three sisters; Fred Warner of Zanesville, Harve Warner, Delaware, James Warner, Batesville, Alva Warner, Barnesville, Mrs. Sarah Roe, Batesville, Jennie Warner and Mrs. Ella Brownfield, Jerusalem rural.
Funeral services was held in the Campbell Funeral Home Wednesday morning at 11:30 in charge of Evangelist Fred Dennis. Interment was made in Somerton. Thursday 27 November. 1927 Barnesville Whetstone.
 
 
Hoyt, Perry H. Source--Wheeling Intelligencer Wheeling, West Virginia Published--Wednesday November 22, 1944s
Perry H.Hoyt, 68, of Hannibal, Ohio, died at 4:30 Tuesday morning at his home. He was a former resident of Wheeling, moving to Hannibal nine years ago. The body will be removed today from the Wharton funeral home to the late residence, time of service to await arrival of a grandson from Camp Fannin, Texas. Burial will be at Hannibal. Born in Moundsville, September 30, 1876, he came to Wheeling when a young man and was employed at the Belmont mill for 32 years. He had been retired for nine years. He was a member of the First Christian Church here and served as deacon of the church for four years. Surviving are his wife, Mary Luvedo Hoyt; three children, Harry and Frank of Wheeling and Mrs. Walter Custer of Wheeling; 11 grandchildren, two brothers, Chester and Jesse Hoyt of Wheeling.

Hubbard: Opal Dallas (Hissom)
Source:Marietta Times . . . Marietta, OH . . . November 2002
Provided by Betty Lendon Matson
Sardis - Opal Dallas Hubbard, 99, of the Monroe County Care Center, formerly of Sardis, died Saturday (November 9, 2002).
She was born October 20, 1903, in Fly to Elsom and Lucinda Billiter Hissom.
She was preceded in death by her husband, HoWard Hissom; her parents; and one brother, Noah Hissom.
She is survived by three children, Doris M. Miller, Mrs. Max (Lavina) Nuzum and Buford Hubbard, all of Sardis; four grandchildren, Mrs. Alvin (Connie) Thompson of Woodsfield, Mrs. Jim (Becky) Harrigan of Sardis, Micky Hubbard and his wife, Cindy, of Cambridge, and Cassandra "Cassie" Hubbard of Sardis; and three great-grandchildren, Neil Thompson of Marietta College, Jared Thompson of Woodsfield and Brittney Harrigan of Sardis.
Services are at 11 a.m. Tuesday at Grisell Funeral Home, 37234 Mound St., Sardis. Burial is in Locust Grove Cemetery in Sardis. The family will receive friends from 2 to 4 p.m. and 7 to 9 p.m. today at the funeral home.

Woodsfield
 
Hudson, Carl
Source--Toothman Memorial Obituaries Saint Clairsville, Ohio
Published--January 2004
Hudson , Carl Edward , 78, of Glencoe died Saturday, January 24, 2004 at Ohio Valley Medical Center in Wheeling.He was born April 26, 1925 in Pultney Township, a son of the late Harry Hudson and Edna Pugh Hudson. He was a retired coal miner from the Ohio Valley Coal Company at Alledonia, a member of the East Richland Evangelical Friends Church, a Navy veteran of World War II, member of Glencoe American Legion Post # 632, and Saint Clair Lanes Senior Bowling League. In addition to his parents, he was preceded in death by his first wife Nora Hudson; a sister, Evelyn LeMaster; a brother, Ernie Hudson. Surviving are his wife Lillian "Lil" Saffell Stull Hudson; three sons, Harry Hudson of Neffs, Pat Hudson of Columbus, and Doug Hudson of Bellaire; two step daughters, Mary Gheen of Glencoe, and Helen Cole of Liberty Center, Ohio; six step sons, John and George McMahon of Glencoe, Douglas and Brian Stull of Sugar Grove, Ohio, Robert Stull of Saint. Clairsville, Dennis Stull of Saint Joe; three brothers, Bill Hudson of Neffs, Mack Hudson of Beallsville, and Earl Hudson of Kentucky; two sisters, Sylvia Hawkins of Lakewood, California, and Mary Matthew of South Gate, California.; three grandchildren; eight step grandchildren, and seven step great grandchildren. Friends will be received at the Toothman Funeral Home in Saint Clairsville on Monday from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. where services will be held on Tuesday at 1 p.m. with Reverend Wayne Ickes and Reverend Douglas Stull officiating. Burial follows in Jacobsburg Cemetery. The Belmont County Council of American Legions will conduct services at 12:45 p.m. Tuesday in the funeral home. Memorial contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society, 3612 Maple Avenue, Zanesville, Ohio 43702.

Huff, Jack A.
Source--Grisell Funeral Home Obituaries
Published--October 4, 2004
 
Huff, Jack A. age 73 of Second Avenue, Bellaire, Ohio, died Monday, October 4, 2004 in Belmont Community Hospital, Bellaire, Ohio.
He was born February 14, 1931, in Fly, Ohio, the son of the late John Robert and Mae Elizabeth Winland Huff.
He was a retired construction worker a member of Union Local #1149, Wheeling and the First Baptist Church.
In addition to his parents he was preceded in death by his wife, Dolly Huff.
Survivors include two sisters, Lucille Rose of New Matamoras, Ohio and Wilma Stackhouse of Orlando, Florida; one brother, Raymond Huff of Orlando; several nieces and nephews, including a special niece, Sandra Edgell of Bellaire, Ohio.
Family will receive friends on Thursday from 2-4 and 7-9pm at The Grisell Funeral Home, 125 Clarinda Drive, Clarington, Ohio, where funeral services will be held on Friday at 1:00pm, with Reverend Frank Conley officiating. Interment in Clarington Cemetery, Clarington, Ohio.
 
Huff, John T.
Source--News Clipping
Published--February 1, 2000
Huff, John T.,61, of 44 West Main Street, Hayesville, died February 1, 2000, at Akron City Hospital. He was born in Fly, September 22, 1938, the son of the late Robert and Mae Elizabeth Winland Huff.
He had been a pump assembler at Hydromatic Pump Company for 30 years. He was a member of the Sardis Baptist Church and had served with the United States Army during the Korean Conflict. He had coached summer ball in Hayesville for many years.
Surviving are his wife, Sara Henthorn Huff, to whom he was married March 29, 1964; two daughters and one son-in-law; Rita Parker, of Loudenville, Mrs. Jeff (Brenda) Fisher, of Hayesville; a son and daughter-in-law, Randy and Rhonda Huff, of Jeromesville; six grandchildren; two brothers, Raymond Huff of Florida, Jack Huff, of Bellaire; four sisters, Deloris Fletcher, of Lorain, Mary Carr, of Cambridge, Lucille Rose, of New Matamoras, Wilma Stackhouse, of Florida and best friend, Richard Taylor, of South Carolina.
In addition to his parents, he was preceded in death by five brothers; four sisters.
Funeral services were held at the Hickes Funeral Home, Jeromesville, February 4, with Dr. Robert Seaman officiating. Burial was in the Vermillion Cemetery, Hayesville, where military rites were conducted.
Memorial contributions may be made to the family to help defray expenses.

Huffman, Erica Nikole and James Stanley Pyles
Source--Times Leader Martins Ferry, Oh.
Published--September 13, 2004
Erica Nikole Huffman and James Stanley Pyles III were united in marriage Sept. 11 at 4:30 .m. in an outdoor ceremony at the Marietta Shrine Club with Minister Josh Hetrick officiating at the double ring ceremony. The bride was given in marriage by her mother, Kerry Williamson. The bride is the daughter of Kerry Wiliamson of Summerfield. The groom is the son of Jim and Marie Pyles of Beallsville. Donielle Phillips was maid of honor and Jay Lang, best man. Other attendants were Jennifer Phillips, Antoinette (Toni) Bolin, Nathan Pittman, Jeremiah (J.J.) Brown, Trevor Schaffer and Zachary Bolin. Flower girls wer Amber Hetrick, Kayla Hetrick, Elizabeth Hetrick and Joscelin Hetrick. Ring bearer was Mason Huffman. Paige Atkinson attended the guest book. Vocalists were Janie and Sam Abbott, Krista West and Jeff Lucas was vocalist and organist. A reception was held at the Marietta Shrine Club in Marietta.The bride is a 2001 graduate of Beallsville High School. She is pursuing a bachelor's degree in exercise physiology at Ohio University Eastern. Her husband is a 2000 graduate of Beallsville High School. He is employed at the Wal-Mart Distribution Center in Wintersville. The newlyweds will reside in Beallsville.

Huffman, Rose Irene (nee Brownfield)
Funeral services were held Monday afternoon at the Brownfield home near Antioch for Mrs. Irene Brownfield Huffman, 61, who passed away Friday evening at her home in Wadsworth. She was a native of Antioch, this County.
Surviving are her husband; her mother, Mrs. Alex Brownfield of Antioch; one sister, Mrs. Emma Smith, also near Antioch and two brothers, John Brownfield in the west and Frank Brownsfield on Antioch.
Funeral services were in charge of Rev. A. R. Brown, pastor of the Woodsfield Methodist Church. Burial was in Antioch Cemetery.

Huffman, Zelma
 
 
January 26, 1927
Source: Monroe County records
Subject: Freda Shai Huggins
 
Freda Shai Huggins
 
Freda Shai Huggins, 86, of Colegate Drive, Marietta, died at 1 p.m. Friday (July 23, 2004) at Marietta Memorial Hospital.
She was born August 26, 1917, in Marietta, the daughter of the late John Victor Shai and Hattie Matilda Mendenhall Shai. She was a member of Faith United Methodist Church, where she was baptized on September 10, 1972. She was also a member of the Daughters of the American Revolution and of Golden Gleam Council Daughters of America. She had been employed at Elberfeld's Store and also at Bonham's of Marietta.
She is survived by several cousins, including Ronald and Julia Wright, with whom she had made her home.
She was married to Earl E. Huggins on January 26, 1957, who preceded her in death. She was also preceded in death by her parents; and a foster sister, Delilia Irene Mendenhall Kendle.
Funeral services will be held at 1 p.m. Tuesday at McClure-Schafer-Lankford Funeral Home with Pastor Steve Gedon officiating. Interment will be in Valley Cemetery. Friends may call from 2 p.m. Sunday until the hour of the services at the funeral home. The family will be present to meet friends from 2 to 4 and 6 to 8 p.m. Sunday and Monday.
Source--Marietta Times Marietta, Ohio
Published--July 26, 2004 provided by betty M.
 
Hughes, Donald
June 13, 1903
July 2, 1988
Woodsfield
 
Hughes, Donald R.--Miracle
Source--News Clipping
Published--1953
On Sunday afternoon, July twenty-sixth, in the chapel of the First Methodist Church at Lancaster, Ohio, Miss Norma L. Miracle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Forrest Miracle, of Stafford, became the bride of Mr. Donald R. Hughes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Hughes, of 206 North Main Street, Woodsfield.
Vows were exchanged at a double ring ceremony at two-thirty o'clock with the Reverend George Herds officiating before an altar decorated with vases of summer flowers.
The bride wore a street-length dress of ice blue silk. Honashans with white accessories and a purple orchid corsage. The tradition of something old, new, borrowed, blue and a penny in her shoe for good luck, was adhered to by the bride.
Mrs. Ruth Winland, of Bremen, sister of the bride, served as matron of honor. She wore a beige dress identical to that of the bride's with beige accessories and a red rosebud corsage.
Mr. Paul Winland, of Bremen, brother-in-law of the bride served Mr.Mr. Hughes as best man.
The bride's mother wore a dress of mauve pink taffeta, with navy accessories and a pink rosebud corsage. The groom's mother wore a navy sheer dress with navy accessories. Her corsage was of red rosebuds.
Following the ceremony a reception was held at the home of the bride's sister, Mrs. Paul Winland in Bremen for members of the immediate families.
Mr. and Mrs. Hughes are graduates of the Stafford High School class of 1946. Mr. Hughes is employed with The Pabst Electric Company in Marietta. They are now at their home near Stafford.

Hughes, John F. Hughes
April 24, 1914
 
Hughes, Maria
Source:The Spirit of Democracy, dated, January 7, 1931
Provided by Lena Kahrig Pettit, typed by Betty Lendon Matson
Mrs. Maria Hughes ,82, died at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Ross Knapp, at New Philadelphia, Sunday morning at 2:00 o'clock. The deceased was the widow of the late Uriah Hughes, Civil War veteran and former resident of near Stafford, and a sister of the late William Barnett, who died two years ago at his home in Caldwell.
Surviving are 2 daughters, Mrs. Knapp, at whose home she died and Mrs. Bertha Quigley, of Columbus, with whom she has made her home since the death of her husband, five years ago.
Funeral services were held on Tuesday afternoon at 2:00 o'clock from The M.E. Church at SutHerland and burial was made in the church cemetery.
 
 
Hughes, Martha E. Hughes
 
November 24, 1904
 
November 30, 1994
 
Woodsfield
 
Hughes, Mary A. Hughes
May 16, 1930
Hughes, Mary A.E.
Death Of Mrs. Hughes
Source:The Spirit of Democracy, dated May 21,1930
On last Friday morning, May 16, Mrs. Mary A.E. Hughes, ( Aunt Mary ), the best known citizen of Stafford, Ohio, and for that matter in South-eastern Ohio, died at her home in that village where she had lived for over sixty years. Death was due to infirmities of advanced age. Frail in body for years, but indomitable in spirit, she lived alone, self-dependent, optimistic and with a philosophy of life that might well have been the envy of many who possibly pitied her on account of apparent loneliness and isolation. And yet she was not alone for she had her books, papers, friends and memories. Perhaps no individual in the County had more contacts with friends local and distant and they played a great part in her life with occasional visits, cards, letters and gifts.
As a child and young woman, she had a newspaper experience in the office of a paper in Woodsfield in which her father Editor Shipley was interested and for half a century possibly she was the Stafford correspondent for the County papers and the reputation of Stafford for rugged honesty, hospitality, interest in education and the good name of her people generally is due to largely to the kindly messages her facile pen sent forth year after year.
Though limited in education in the ordinary sense of the word, she wrote eloquently of the virtues and lives of those whom she knew intimately and her letters were read for their merit alone, by many who knew little or nothing of Stafford or her people.
Mrs. Hughes was born at Londonderry in Guernsey County on May 30, 1842, moving to Woodsfield with her parents at the age of five years. She spent her girlhood there and at the age of twenty-one came to Stafford where she lived the rest of life.
In 1867 she was married to Capt. Thomas Hughes, who engaged in the mercantile business and was appointed postmaster at Stafford, the office being located where her late home now stands.
Their five children, two of them twins, die in infancy, and in 1872, her husband passed to The Great Beyond; two foster daughters, one died early in life and the other Mrs. Charles S. McVey, of East Liverpool, Ohio survives her. Other near relatives include a cousin, Miss Ora Little of Cambridge; and Donald Hughes of Stafford.
Funeral services were held Sunday afternoon at the home in charge of Rev. E. N. Miller, and at her quest were characterized by briefness and simplicity. Interment was made in the family lot in Stafford.
 
 
 
Hughes, Mercedes Hughes
 
September 9, 1913
 
September 1978
 
Woodsfield
 
Hughes, Richard Hughes
 
 
June 1, 1934
 
 
Hughes, Robert Hughes
 
October 17, 1900
 
February 1970
 
Woodsfield
 
Hughes, Rose Hughes
 
 
March 5, 1936
 
 
Hughes, Uriah Hughes
April 10, 1928
Hughes, Uriah
Source:The Spirit of Democracy, dated April 25, 1928
Provided by Lena Kahrig Pettit, typed by Betty Lendon Matson
Uriah Hughes, son of Benjamin and Elizabeth Hughes, a prominent pioneer family famous in connection with the historical Underground Railroad of slavery times was born in Woodsfield, Ohio May 28, 1842; and completed his earthly life, April 19, 1928 being 85 years, 10 months and 12 days old.
He was baptized in the Christian faith by Rev. C. W. Danford at Bellaire,Ohio and united with The M.E. Church at SutHerlands some years ago.
He enlisted in Co. F. 51st. Ohio Volunteer Infantry and was mustered out at the close of the war. He was a faithful member of John Archilbald Post of the G. A. R. at Stafford, being the last of Civil War veterans of Franklin Township.
Uriah, born in Woodsfield spent his early life in that vicinity, moving to a farm near Lewisville, when he was six years old. At the age of seven, the family came to the present farm home, where he lived until November 1925, at that time moving to the Stafford home.
Veteran Hughes had been a partial invalid for a number of years. In January 1927, he unfortunately fell sustaining injuries that in a few days confined him to his room. He suffered much during the last few days; yet he exhibited the soldier's endurance with few complaints, his patience at times reaching almost the sublime.
Mr. Hughes was the last one of the family of twelve children to receive the Devine call that his life's work was ended. Two, of the children Walter and Mary, died in infancy. The following, Albert, David, William, Thomas, Allen, Theodore, James, Winifred and Elizabeth growing to manhood and womanhood.
Uriah Hughes was united in marriage to Maria, daughter of John and Rebekah Barnett, November 18,1875. Three children were given to bless the home. The son, William B. Hughes died April 15, 1906. He leaves to mourn, a wife and two daughters, Mrs. Bertha Quigley, of Columbus; and Mrs. Martha A. Knapp of New Philadelphia; six grandchildren, Charles W. and Donald U. Hughes, Mrs. William Shaw, Willene and Gerald Quigley and Ruth Knapp. Three grandchildren have preceded him in death; Mildred, Wilma and Winifred Hughes. The great grandchildren are Mildred, Charlotte Mae and William Hughes, also Hughes Shaw, all of Dover,Ohio.
We need not eulogize Mr. Hughes character, it has lived and will continue to live with honor in this community where he has spent his entire life.
Funeral services were conducted by a former pastor, Rev. S.G. Suitor of Byesville, at SutHerlands Church. The remains were laid to rest in The SutHerlands Cemetery.

Humphrey--Liberatore
Source--Times Leader Martins Ferry, Ohio
Published--February 18, 2005
Dr. and Mrs. Frederic Humphrey of Marietta, Ohio announce the engagement of their daughter, Nicole Elizabeth Humphrey, to Ty William Liberatore, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Liberatore of Bellaire. The bride-elect is a 1997 graduate of Marietta High School and a 2003 graduate of Ohio University, with a bachelor of science degree in health. She is employed by Tri-County Help Center in Saint Clairsville. Her fiance is a 1994 graduate of Saint John Central in Bellaire and a 1998 graduate of Ohio University, with a bachelor of science degree. He is employed by Woodsfield Nursing and Rehabilitation in Woodsfield as the sales and marketing director. A June 18 wedding is planned.

Hunnell, Rosana Hunnell
 
 
October 5, 1913
 
 
Hunnell, Vada Hunnell
February 28, 1902
May 1985
Woodsfield

Death

May 1, 1985

Vada L. Hunnell, nee Pfalzgraf

Woodsfield-Vada L. Hunnell, 83, of Woodsfield R. D. 4, died Wednesday afternoon (May 1, 1985) at her home.

She was born Feb. 28, 1902, in Monroe County, daughter of the late Lewis and Martha Walton McKelvey Pfalzgraf.

Mrs. Hunnell was a member of Woodsfield Presbyterian Church.

Her husband, John S. Hunnell, preceded her in death in May 1969.

She leaves three daughters, Mrs. William (Ruth) Dennison of Woodsfield, R.D. 4, Mrs. Joseph (Helen) Reed of Woodsfield R. D. 1 and Mrs. Bernard (Ethel) Walton of Akron; 16 grandchildren; 29 great-grandchildren; two great great-grandchildren and one brother, Raymond Pfalzgraf of Clarington R.D. 1.

Friends may cal 2 to 9 p.m. today at Bauer-Turner Funeral Home in Woodsfield, where services will be 1 p.m. Friday with the Rev. Stephen Long officiating. Burial will be in Pleasant Ridge Cemetery, Adams Township, Woodsfield, R.D. 4.

 
Huntsman, Clinton Ray
Clinton Ray Huntsman, 2-months old, died suddenly Monday morning, December 16, 1991, at Barnesville Hospital. Born in Cambridge, October 18, he was the son of Eric L. and Christina Lynn Huntsman, 36692 Co. Rd # 122, Barnesville.
Besides his parents, he leaves one brother, Shawn Eric Huntsman, of the home; paternal grandparents, Paulette Gray and Harry (Butch) Huntsman, both of Barnesville; maternal grandparents Dana Huntsman
of Barnesville and Raymond Lynn, of Cambridge.
Also surviving are paternal greatgrandparents, Lucille Agin of Barnesville and Harry Huntsman, Sr. of California; maternal greatgrandparents, Richard and Grace Richmond of Barnesville and Dorothy Bonnell of Cambridge; and maternal great-great-grandmother, Goldie Johnson of West Virginia.
Friends will be received Wednes ]day at 10 a.m. until time of the funeral at 1 p.m. at Campbell-Plumly ]Milburn Funeral Home. Minister M. Gale Yoho will conduct the services: Burial will be in Crestview Cemetery.
 
 
Huntsman, Harry
Toronto - Harry Earl Huntsman, 85, of RD 1, Toronto, died Friday, July 28, 1995, at St. John Medical Center in Steubenville.
He was born March 2, 1910, in Boston, a son of the late Allen and Melissa Jane Davis Huntsman. He was married to Edna Morris Huntsman, who survives. Huntsman was a retired employee of Nelson Tree Service in Dayton and was a member of Vet ]erans of Foreign Wars Post 6906. Surviving, in addition to his wife, are three sons, Marvin of Sacramento, Calif., Harry L. of Barnesville and Joseph of Jones ]Boro, Georgia; five daughters, Mrs. Clifford (Sylvia) Spencer of Toronto, Mrs. Harold (Betty) Baker of Lower Salem, Mrs. Ray (Thelma) Hicks of Channelview, Texas, Mrs. Francis (Edna) Lucas, of Bethesda and Mrs. James (Janet) Rock of Toronto; one sister Mrs. Clarence (Bertha) Morris of Ashland; 49 grandchildren; 70 great-grandchildren and 10 great-great-grandchildren.
In addition to his parents, he was preceded in death by two sons, Charles H. and Francis M.; one daughter, Martha Howell three brothers; seven sisters; three grandsons; and one great ]great-grandson.
 
Calling hours are from 7-9 p.m. today and 2-4 and 7-9 p.m. Sunday at the Clarke Funeral Home, 32 Main St. Services will be held there Monday at 1 p.m. with the Reverend Wayne Hogue officiating. Burial will follow at Island Creek Cemetery.
 
 Funeral for Harry Earl Huntsman July 31, 1995 Clarke Funeral Home Rev. Wayne A. Hogue
It was not my privilege to know Harry Huntsman while he lived, I'm sorry to say. I would have liked to have known him when he was in his prime; when he worked for the Nelson Tree Company; when he and
Edna were raising 11 children. 1 would have liked to have heard some of the stories he could tell of his experiences growing up and then raising a family. But having met some of his family, including his wife of 66 years, I feel like I know him a little bit.
Let us look to the Word of God to find some comfort in this hour. David the Psalmist said in the 23rd Psalm: "The Lord is my shepherd, / shall not want. He maketh me to lie down in green pastures; he leadsth me beside the still waters; he restoreth my soul. He leadeth me !n the paths of righteousness for his name's sake. Yea, though / walk through the valley of the shadow of death, / will fear no evi/, for thou art with me. Thy rod and thy staff, they comfort me. Thou preparest a table before me in the presence of mine enemies Thou annointest my head with of my cup runneth over Surely goodness and mercy shall follow me a// the days of my life, and / will dwell in the house of the Lord forever. "
Job reminds us that: "Man that is born of a woman is of few days, and full of trouble. He cometh forth like a flower, and is cut down: he fleeth also as a shadow, and continueth not."
The writer of Ecclesiastes tells us: "Then shall the dust return to the earth as it was; and the spirit shall return unto God who gave it. "
Let us pray: O God, You understand the pain that is felt by the family of Harry Earl Huntsman in his passing. And even though he was ill the last 12 years, struggling with trying to breathe through lungs that were failing, still he will be missed by all who knew him. Comfort the hearts today of Edna, his beloved wife of 66 years and the children who survived him: Marvln, Harry, Joseph, Sylvia, Janet, Betty, Thelma, and Edna; his sister Bertha; his 49 grandchildren; 70 great-grandchildren; and 10 great-great-grandchildren. Be with all those who mourn his passing today and in the days to come. We ask this in the name of Jesus. Amen.
pg 2 Harry Earl's funeral
 
Harry Earl Huntsman was what you might call a free spirit for most of his 85 years. He lived life to the fullest, taking the good with the bad. He enjoyed life; enjoyed a good story, which in his prime, he could tell with the best of them.
For 66 years, his beloved Edna stood at his side and was his helper at every turn of the road. The shared many experiences together - including the deaths of two sons, Charles and Francis; their daughter Martha; 3 brothers, 7 sisters, 3 grandsons; and a great-great-grandson. They were together through his illness which lasted 12 years, when he battled the infected lungs. She listened to his stories over and over again. She laughed at his jokes. She held his hand when he was hurting. They faced whatever life through their way - they faced it together.
What they went through together would make a good-sized book of memories. Life will not be the same for you, Edna. But be thankful for all the memories that you had together. You were there when he needed you. It was hard to see him suffer like he did in recent years. But you were at his bedside through It all. And that isn't easy to do - especially when it is someone that you love.
Harry came from a family of 12 children. Only Bertha remains from that family. He and Edna were parents to 11 children (of whom 8 survive). Then came that long, large line of descendants that followed: 49 + 70 + 10. That's 140 descendants - from the union of Harry and Edna. I don't think that Harry in his wildest imagination would leave that many relatives when he died. If children are a heritage of the Lord, Harry certainly had a huge heritage. Perhaps Adam and Eve or Abraham in the Bible left that many descendants, but I don't know of many today who could make such a boast.
For many years Harry worked for the Nelson tree Service Company out of Dayton, Ohio (although he usually worked locally). When he retired from that occupation, he was not content to settle down to a rocking chair. He had to be busy. So he took over the job of custodian at the American Legion here in Toronto, a job which he held as long as he was able.
Harry was not a lazy person. He came through the Depression and knew what it meant to work hard to provide for his growing family. They struggled at times to put food on the table and clothes on the backs and shoes on the feet of his family. But survive they did and grew to respect the value of hard work and a job well done.
It was not easy for Edna during those years either to provide so many- meals on so little money. But with everyone pitching in to help, the work was done.
 
But the struggles together brought them closer together as they faced difficult times, and joys, and challenges as a team and a family.
 
Harry will be missed by all who knew and loved him. When you remember him, remember the good times that you shared together; remember the funny things that happened; remember the stories that he told. But don't just remember them. Share them with each other. You have all suffered the loss of this patriarch of the family. You will all experience times of sadness and grief. But you don't have to suffer alone. Lean on each other. Find strength in your family. Remember the good times.
 
Also remember that the funeral is a time to consider our own mortality. As Harry Earl Huntsman lived and then died, so all of us who are living will one day die. Life is a preparation time for eternity. Harry has finished the work that he can accomplish on this earth. Your work must continue. Harry would only want you to be successful in whatever you do.
 
God loves you and wants to be your comforter as you sorrow over your loss. Don't grieve alone. Lean on Him; let God be your source of strength today and in the days to come.
 
Let us pray: O God, we have stopped today to consider that all of us are human. It is appointed uo us once to die. Help us to prepare for that appointment by putting our trust in You. Amen.
 
Huntsman, Harry, Sr.
The Times Leader, Page 1 of 1
Harry L. "Dyner" Huntsman, Sr. 71, of Barnesville, died Saturday at his home. He was born Feb. 14, 1931 in Woodsfield.
Dyner served in the Marine Corps and was a member of the VFW Post 2792, American Legion Post 168, LOOM and FOE.
He was preceded in death by his father, Earl Huntsman; two brothers; a sister, and two great grandsons.
Surviving are his mother, Edna Huntsman of St. Clairsville; two sons, Butch Huntsman and wife Dana of Barnesville and Alan Huntsman and wife Debbie of Bethesda; three daughters, Mrs. Jerry (Sharon) Buzzard of Pennsylvania, Mrs. Earl (Diana) Showalter and Kathy Huntsman, both of Barnesville; two brothers, Marvin Huntsman of California and Joe "Sonny" Huntsman of Georgia; five sisters, Sylvia Spencer of Toronto, Betty Baker of Caldwell, Edna Lucas of Bethesda, Thelma Hicks of Texas and Janet Rock of Toronto; 19 grandchildren and 27 great grandchildren.
Friends will be received 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. Tuesday, at Campbell Plumly Funeral Home, 319 N. Chestnut Street, Barnesville, Ohio, where services will be held at 11 a.m. Wednesday. Burial follows in Crestview Cemetery, Barnsville.
Military graveside services will be conducted by Belmont County Council of the VFW.

Huntsman, Roger W.
Source--Newsclipping
Published--March 2000
Huntsman, Roger W., 75, of 127 South Lincoln Avenue, Barnesville, died Monday
March 27, 2000 at Southeastern Ohio Regional Medical Center, Cambridge. He was
born Januaryuary 17, 1925 in Somerton, a son of Lester and Myrtle Stephen Huntsman.
He was a retired dispatcher with the Barnesville Police Department, a Protestant,
a member of Federal Order of Police, Lodge 6, 50 year member of I.O.O.M. of
Lions Club and canteen member of VFW Post 2792 of Barnesville.
In addition to his parents, he was preceded in death by two brothers, Francis and
Delbert Huntsman.
Surviving are his wife, Ruth Philips Huntsman; a daughter, Mrs. George (Pam)
Hoover of Beallsville; a step-son, Ronald Linville of Columbus; a step-daughter,
Regina Kindler of Florida; four sisters, Lena Hannahs, Ruby Hannahs, Melba Swallie
and Mrs Francis (Joan) Gallagher, all of Barnesville; seven grandchildren; six
great-grandchildren.
Friends will be received Thursday 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 at Campbell-Plumly-Milburn
Funeral Home, Barnesville, where services will be held Friday at 1 p.m. with Pastor Tim
Adams officiating. Burial follows in Crestveiw Cemetery, Barnesville.
I.O.O.M. services will be held Thursday at 6:45 p.m. at the funeral home.

Hupp, Vonnie Eleanor (Forshey)
Source:Marietta Times . . . Marietta, OH . . . 15 Apr 2002
Provided by Betty Lendon Matson
MACKSBURG - Vonnie Eleanor Hupp, 86, of Macksburg died Sunday morning (April 14, 2002) at Selby General Hospital in Marietta.
She was born December 4, 1915, in Archers Fork, Monroe County, to Jesse Adam and Hazel Mae Tice Forshey. She was a homemaker who loved sewing, reading and flower gardening. She was a Protestant by faith.
She is survived by two sons, Floyd E. (Charlene) Thompson of Caldwell and Raymond (Carol) Hupp of Macksburg; eight grandchildren; 20 great-grandchildren; one great-great-grandchild; and numerous nieces and nephews.
She was preceded in death by her husband, James Leroy Hupp, on May 27, 1983; her parents; one brother, Foster Forshey; and two sisters, Mildred VanFossen and Maxine "Dot" Moore.
Services are at 11 a.m. Tuesday at McVay-Perkins Funeral Home in Caldwell with the Rev. William Pickenpaugh officiating. Burial is in Stafford Cemetery. Friends may call from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. today at the funeral home

Hutchison, Anna
Born: January 29, 1899, died: Mar 1986, residence:Beallsville, Ohio
Source: Monroe County records
 
Hutchison, Arthur "Sam" "Pops"
Source--Monroe County Beacon Woodsfield, Ohio
Published--Thursday, June 17, 2004
Hutchison, Arthur "Sam" "Pops" ,81, Beallsville, died June 11, 2004 at his home. He was born November 28, 1922, near Cameron, a son of the late Robert and Anna Mellott Hutchison.
He was a retired farmer and a United States Army veteran of World War II. He was held in a German Prisoner of War Camp from which he escaped after five and one half months. He was a member of The Church of Christ, Beallsville.
Surviving are his wife of 52 years, Charlotte Brown Hutchison; seven sons, Lee (Lisa) , Dale, Samuel (Corilda), Larry, Harold, and James Hutchison , all of Beallsville, and Gary, of North Carolina; three daughters, Mary Lucas, of Beallsville, Betty (Jeff) Farr and Melissa (Todd) Cherry, both of North Carolina; two brothers, James, of New Matamoras and Carl "Nick" of Rittman; two sisters, Marjorie Foltz, of Beallsville, Martha McIntire, of Piedmont; 14 grandchildren; six great great-grandchildren.
In addition to his parents, he was preceded in death by an infant son, Arthur, Jr.; a brother; three sisters.
Friends were received June 13 at Harper Funeral home, Beallsville, where services were held June 14. Burial followed in Cameron Cemetery with full military honors by American Legion Post 768.
Memorial contributions may be made to The Hutchison Family, 49879 Hutchison Road
Beallsville, Ohio 43716

Hyer, Mary Lou Thompson
Source--The Intelligencer Wheeling, West Virginia
Published--April 20, 2005
THOMPSON, Mary Lou, 77, of
Hannibal, Ohio, died Tuesday, April 19, 2005 in the Wetzel County Hospital, New Martinsville, West Virginia. She was born June 15, 1927 in Hannibal, the daughter of the late Paul and Lina Chaplin Hyer. She was a member of the Ladies Auxiliary of Veterans of Foreign Wars 9930, Duffy, Ohio, the American Legion 28 of New Martinsville, and a member of the Hannibal United Methodist Church. In addition to her parents, she was preceded in death by her husband, Nile E. Thompson on March 10, 2004; a sister, Ethel Rose Matheny; a granddaughter, Marsha Lynn Thompson. Survivors include a son, Steve (Judy) Thompson of Hannibal. There will be no visitation. A graveside service will be held Friday at 11 a.m. for Nile E. Thompson and Mary Lou Thompson at Emma Grove Cemetery, Hannibal, Ohio. American Legion Post 760 will conduct military graveside services. Memorial contributions may be made to the Sardis Emergency Squad, Post Office Box 7, Sardis, Ohio 43946. Sympathy expressions at www.grisellfuneralhomes.com
 
Hyer, Paul
Apr 14, 1899
November 1975
Hannibal
 
Hyland, Richard
Source--Times Leader Martins Ferry, Ohio
Published--July 30, 2004
Richard C. "Dick" Hyland, 69, of Powhatan Point, Ohio, died Thursday, July 29, 2004, at his home after a brave battle with cancer. He was born in Powhatan Point on April 26, 1935, a son of the late Irwin and Alta Carney Hyland.Dick was a graduate of Powhatan High School, a veteran of the US Navy, serving aboard the USS Iowa, and a retiree of the Ohio Ferro Alloy Corporation at Powhatan Point and Titus Construction of Dayton. He served as a councilman for the village of Powhatan Point and was a former board member of the Powhatan Library Board. He was an avid reader and devoted Cleveland Browns and Pittsburgh Pirates fan. He was a Protestant by faith. In addition to his parents, Dick was preceded in death by his sister, Betty Sabec; two nephews, David and Douglas Sabec; and his faithful companion, Maggie. Surviving are his wife of 42 years, Ruth Ann Bryan Hyland; two daughters, Laura Ann McCormick, and her husband, Buddy, of Dublin, Ohio, and Jennifer Brown, and her husband, David, of Powhatan Point; two grandchildren, Alexandra McCormick and Cade Brown; three brothers, John Hyland, of Indian Lake, Ohio, Paul (Marcy) Hyland, of Kettering, Ohio, and Tom (Donna) Hyland, of Centreville, Va. Also, several nieces and nephews. Friends will be received at the Bauknecht-Altmeyer Funeral Homes and Crematory, 186 Main Street, Powhatan Point, Ohio, on Sunday, from noon to 4 p.m. and 6 to 8 p.m., where services will be held on Monday, at 11 a.m., with the Rev. Ric Hendrix officiating. Interment will be in the Powhatan Cemetery in Powhatan Point. Memorial contributions may be made to the Powhatan Elementary School Library Fund, Powhatan Elementary School, Powhatan Point, Ohio 43942, or the Belmont County Animal Shelter, 45244 National Road., St. Clairsville, Ohio 43950.
